Tokyo maybe yes, but outside Tokyo and other major cities in Japan, from my experience, local residents don't like mass tourism in their areas. It violates their principles of collectivism, and a homogenous population living in harmony with each other. They don't want foreign tourists 'polluting' that ideology.

I would also recommend if you do go to Hiroshima check out gethiroshima.com  The people running the magazine and website have been living in Japan for a very long time and they found the best places to eat with a wide but reasonable price range for locals and travelers. They also write about up coming events in the city and hidden attractions that may interest travelers looking to go off of the beaten path.

Yes and no. It all depends where you live. I work in a very rural town that is split when it comes to foreigners, if you do travel with a group into places like this I recommend having a friend or yourself,Â whom is able to speak some Japanese. Worse comes to worse you can use google translate but I would advise against it. Other than that the closer you get to the city the more you will see people who are friendlier towards foreigners.   Another interesting thing is that with English being taught in school, children and young adults want to test their English skills on you. They are also very curious of the outside world and want to learn more about it. In time and with the push by the Japanese government to start children learning English at younger ages you will start to see the youth of Japan become a bilingual generation.

I prefer APA hotels (Nagoya Nishiki mostly) because of the hard beds (and good location). You can get from Nagoya to Tokyo in 1,5 hours and to Hiroshima in 2,5 hours, to Kyoto in 37 minutes. I've found it to be a nice "base of operations". If you need to spend more time in Tokyo or Hiroshima or anywhere else -> capsule hotel. But I like riding the shinkansen so I happily waste 3 hours a day going back and forth   My usual budget is around 3500â‚¬ everything included (direct flights 750-800â‚¬, hotel 730-850â‚¬, JRPass 320-430â‚¬, F1 tickets 100-140â‚¬ and spending 100â‚¬ per day) so I would say your budget was spot on for a great holiday. :D  Oh and anyone going to Japan, I would recommend hyperdia.com for train timetables and such. You can opt-out those Nozomi / Mizuho / Hayabusa shinkansens and non-JR trains.

I.B.  In my experience, touring around Japan for over 20 years, I have only run into ONE less than awesomely polite experience.  That was when I entered an izakaya at midday and encountered a grandfather who was leaving.  He muttered something a little less than polite, doubtless assuming I would not understand.  To be fair, he was of the age that he probably fought in WWII, so it was understandable.   Anyway, when I addressed him using keigo (very polite Japanese), as one should when addressing elders in Japan, he was shocked and hastily excused himself.   I guess my point is, if you are polite and respectful of Japanese culture you will very rarely run into anything less than an amazing welcome anywhere in Japan.

Abroad in Japan A Manga-cafe is a great place to sleep if you don't have a reservation. Usually under 20$ for 8-12h including hot drinks and a PC. Also over TripAdvisor I found enough hostels starting at 10$ a night, and enough capsule hotels starting at 15$ all over Japan. One capsule hotel in Tokyo I can recommend is Capsule Value Kanda. I payed 12â‚¬ a night, and it is 1 stop from Akihabara and Tokyo station. Also very nice and clean, with a traditional Japanese bath. Thought the capsules are a bit older. In Kyoto I stayed in a private double room with a friend for 10â‚¬ a person (20â‚¬ in total) per night. The place was called small world guest house. It was a bit far from the city centre and the room was tiny, but it was still good, and the building was a very old traditional Japanese House.

Even in Tokyo you could get a solid 1 bedroom hotel for around 50 USD. I could rough it in a hostel or capsule hotel for even cheaper, or opt for an airbnb. I've seen them as low as 15-20 dollars. For transportation, if you're going around the country then a Japan Rail Pass is a no-brainer. But per day in Tokyo I was spending 10-15 USD on trains, and maybe 20~ on food. Both of these costs could have dropped if I walked more (I was already doing 10+ miles a day on foot) and I was at times buying snacks/etc. If you really wanted to ball on a budget, you could do Tokyo for a week for 650 USD round trip (with layover/connection I just flew into Tokyo from Newark for 750 round trip in the middle of July via Air Canada) and allocate 75 dollars a day for food, hostel/capsule or airbnb and public transit. So all in all with airfare included you could do Tokyo for just shy of 1,200 USD.

I spent about $2000 not counting plane tix on my trip last October, which was a goodly 2 1/2 weeks in Tokyo -> Kyoto -> Osaka. Probably about half of that was room/transportation/tourist fees and I spent the rest on food and late night drinking (I developed a taste for cheap combini enabled oolong highballs). We got the 14 JR pass for convenience and I can vouch for Airbnb being a very viable option for a group of four or more. We got a quiet apartment in Asakusa next to Sensoji Temple and an elementary school so every morning was punctuated by the sound of bells and pleasant school chimes. In Kyoto we splurged a little and got an entire three story house (with a full bath setup, very nice) to ourselves right next to the Kamogawa central area so everything was within walking distance. In Osaka, the apartment was pretty small but it was also right next to the Dotonburi strip and Kuromon Market so I ate myself to ruin. No regrets.
Abroad in Japan Hey! I really want to visit Japan one day and want to learn the language. But is English used a lot in Japan? (Just curiosity)

You probably shouldn't expect most people to understand English fluently but in the major cities, you can get by in most tourist interactions with a phrase book/app and an apologetic bow. Ordering food for example, you can often ask for a English menu (eigo no menu wa arimasu ka?) and learning to count for people and for food items goes a long way. Subway and train stations also have plenty of romaji and English phrase signage for tourists in major cities so as long as you pay attention and give yourself time to acclimate to the reality that they will be punctual even if you are not, you can get by.

Take the JR Yamanote Line to Shinjuku Station then hop on the JR Chuo Sobu Line to Akihabara Station, so as you exit the Station you can't miss it. Price is 200 Yen each way about $1.80 US as of today's exchange rate.  Don't bother with a bike you'll be walking short distance to your destinations and won't need one also you don't want to waste money plus time and the hassle looking for places to park and store it.

My biggest tip is if you want to go to a nice restaurant then go at lunch time. They normally do a lunch special which is pretty cheap compared to their dinner prices and super tasty. Then for dinner time you can go somewhere cheap like sukiya or just get a 711 bentou. I managed to travel for 3 months from Okinawa to Sapporo spending Â¥400,000 or $4000 for the whole time including food Accomodation travel and tourist attractions (starting and ending in Yamaguchi so this includes flights from/to there) The south (Kyushu and Okinawa) is much cheaper than the North because they have cheaper and more choice of hostels and a fantastic bus system so I spent half of the time there and the other half traveling the main island and Hokkaido in the North I bought multiple Seishun 18 Kinpu (a ticket for local trains which you can use  in the main tourist/holiday seasons) and traveled that way which is good to do if you have a little more time to travel as it can take sometimes 3 times longer to get somewhere rather than using the Shinkansen but it's great to use if you want to go to multiple places on the same day along a specific route (make sure to avoid the rush hour if you're traveling with a backpack or everyone will hate you)

We spent two weeks in Japan this year with the 2nd week falling on Golden Week, so things weren't exactly 'cheap'. However, we did get what I think are nice deals at the business hotels as you mentioned. In particular, we stayed at the Tokyo Hotel Mystays in Asakusabashi (right next to Asakusabashi station) and at the Kyoto Hotel Mystays near Shijo station. Nice clean hotels, very helpful staff. We're not much for fancy food so we did as you suggested and we were eating breakfasts from the selections at Lawsons, 7/11, Fresco, FamilyMart, etc. I tended to go for ramen a lot when we ate out simply because I wanted real ramen, not what we generally get in the US. Oddly, I miss the cheap treats at 7/11 a lot. While we ended up spending about $2000 US on hotels for the whole trip we didn't spend a cent on air travel because of frequent flyer miles.

if you're in japan for a long time and in certain periods the seishun 18 kippu is amazing. it's something like 15 days that don't need to be done sequentially i.e. most JR passes are for a period of time say 14 days and if you only take a train on day 1 and day 14 you pass is still expired, whereas this ticket goes by days used and it comes out to something crazy like 2000 yen a use and you can use all none fast trains in essence (i can't recall if it also gives you free busses or not). so the trips take a super long time but it's really cheap and you end up seeing some interesting places.

CamWattsYourProblem the ticket is five days of travel and it has a limit on the time period of use but it's not as short as the jr pass (sometimes upwards of a month) and times when you can buy it they are normally available around new year, Sakura season and the summer holidays.

@CammWatts: Remember that the JRPass also gets you in the majority of the commuter trains in the bigger cities like Tokyo and Osaka; that's a real convenience to not have to figure out the correct ticket price to purchase rather than just being admitted to the station. Using those trains to get around will eat several dollars every day. Also, the JRPass tickets come in one week durations (7-day, 14-day, 21-day). The cost for a 7-day JRPass is almost identical to the price of a round trip shinkansen ticket from Tokyo to Osaka. So, you only need one decent sized side trip each week to more than pay for the cost of the pass. But, if you're going to get a pass, I'd advise making the most of it. We're planning a two week trip to Japan next year where we'll spend a week based in Tokyo and a week based in Osaka. We're planning day trips to Fuji, Nagano, Himeji, Hiroshima, Kyoto, etc., not counting the round trip between Tokyo and Osaka. Bought piecemeal, these trips would cost well over $1000 USD; the two weeks JRPass is about $600.

I went to Japan last month, and I spent in total 2000 usd or around Â£1550 for accomodation transport, food, souvenir and tickets for universal studio and disneysea. my destinations: osaka, nara, kobe, kyoto, then tokyo I bought 2 separate ticket, from my home country to osaka, and for returning home ticket from tokyo to my home country (saves a lot of time and money if you know where do you wanna go first)   IMO, if you wanna travel really cheap, they have kansai through pass which costs 5000 yen for 3 days. it covers all non jr train in kansai area which are: osaka, kyoto nara, kobe, etc (also cover buses).  kyoto has their own city pass costs 2000 yen for 3 days and covers all buses and non jr train inside kyoto (do take bus there, kyoto is beautiful) tokyo has their own city railway ticket, which costs 1500 yen for 3 days (not including bus I think) the main problem is.. jr train has the most strategic stations in all cities that I went. for example jr station will have their station right in the middle of akihabara, while non jr one needs like 5 mins walking to center akihabara. but the do much cheaper, so..  for food, Imo, it is your loss if you don't try some interesting food there, but yeah, I usually buy my breakfast in advance, such as onigiri or instant ramen in convenient store  lastly, dessert and souvenirs are expensive there, try to hold back a bit for it if you are on budget, or, buy souvenirs in daisho (all 108 yen unless stated) they have interesting items.. from food and drinks, souvenir, to beauty products, to party props, and many games (such as nano blocks, magic trick, etc)  and based on my experience: surprisingly, I found out that it is cheaper to buy drinks from vending machine than convenient store

The vending machines are ubiquitous. If one seems slightly more pricey than usual, just walk a few blocks down to the next one or so and it'll probably be several yen cheaper depending on locale and rotation. I found myself hitting the Dekavita C energy drinks hard whenever I needed a pick me up on a long day of walking around.

Best way to fly from SFO is direct to NRT, hands down. Don't settle for connection layover flights, they're a trap and waste your time and patience more than the money they save since oftentimes, they'll end up flying directly over Japan on the way to the connection hub and then you'll spend another 2-3 hours flying back.  That being said, you'll be looking at anywhere from 800-1k after fees and taxes unless you score a heck of a deal or have the flexibility to fly standby.

One of my tips for finding accommodation on a budget is to talk to the friendly people at JR Tours in the major train stations.  I haven't been back to Japan in a while, but when I went, wifi wasn't freely available enough to be useful, and anything online usually involved finding an internet cafe.  JR Tours will let you know what the cheapest rates are for however many nights you will be staying anywhere, can reserve the place for you, and give you a map to get there.  That said, I do recommend the business hotels, as I can't sleep on a moving vehicle.    Also, when you buy food at a convenience store, they will often ask you if you want it warmed.  You can ask them to warm anything in the microwave behind the counter.

I can second this. Me and some friends went to Japan for two weeks this summer and got an AirBnB in Shinjuku for approximately $31 per person per night. It was a private apartment with 4 beds, a washing machine and our own bathroom. It was small but very clean and had airco (a must during the hot and humid summer months). It had self check-in so it was very convenient regarding arrival time. After that we got a guest house in Kyoto for about $29.5 per person per night. Two bedrooms with comfy futons, a nice living room, washing machine again, small kitchen... Shop around on booking sites and you can get excellent deals. As for food, with a bit of research and Yelp/Google Maps work you'll find fantastic options for good prices, and the 24/7 convenience stores will have you covered for breakfast and basic necessities.

Me and my husband just recently finally got to go to Japan albeit just for 12 days and we only stuck to Tokyo and Kyoto, because we rather wanted to chill at fewer places than spending most of our time commuting to destinations and changing Hotels. We went off season and didn't find our trip any more expensive than doing city trips to any other larger cities. We were quite surprised the trip turned out a lot less expensive than we had expected.  We opted for budget hotels at around 80 to 90 Euros a night, both quite central and perfectly connected via metro. If we had been still in our 20s we might have gone for even cheaper options (hostels and capsules) which were also available in plenty around our travel time (late November, early December). But in your late 30s you kind of appreciate a bit more privacy and can afford it. We used the JR Rail pass for our commute from and to Narita. You are right, that airport is a pain to get to and from, but with NEX which is included in the JR pass it was both easy and comfortable and the flights to Narita were a whole lot cheaper than to Haneda. As we were also planning to go to Kyoto via Shinkansen (Hikari line is also covered by JR Rail Pass) it fit together perfectly that way. As for commuting within cities we got ourselves two Welcome Suica cards at the airport (I think this tourist version is pretty new) and charged 5000 yen on each of them. We used it extensively both in Tokyo and Kyoto and still had each 1000 yen left at the end of our trip, so we could have even charged it with less. We only used cabs four times, that is to get from Tokyo/Kyoto station to our Hotel and back with our luggage and our hotels were always close enough that it was never more than 2000 yen. As for food, it was literally just like European prices, you go for pricey food you get a 100 Euro bill, you go for down to earth cheap food you get a 15 euro bill. Towards the end we really tried hard to spend our coin that we had brought along in cash on souvenirs and gifts, unwilling to exchange our yen back and lose more in the process. We still ended up taking quite a few bills back home with us. Now we're saving them in hopes we'll get to go to Japan some time again.  Seriously, we live in Mumbai, I am originally from Munich, we also lived in San Francisco and Santiago de Chile before, also we traveled to Paris, Madrid, London, New York and other comparable cities. At least as long as you stick to well connected bigger cities Japan is really not more expensive than any other bigger city worldwide. Frankly, as for food we felt prices were on perfectly European level. Mumbai and San Francisco can be way more expensive in that regard. Commuting was easily cheaper than Munich both with cab or metro. Hotel prices also were on average European level. But again, mind we came really off season. I am sure for Hanami and the likes you'll be shelling out triple for accommodation. Else it really depends on how high you want to spend. If need be you can eat very cheap (like Ramen was a go to for us, cheap and fills you up good. wouldn't recommend every day though or your arteries will scream in agony).  Anyway, for the longest time in my mind Japan was a travel destination I felt was too expensive for me, cause that's the image created about it. But seriously the biggest part was the flight itself, rest all was just like any other bigger city trip.

When it comes to buying airplane tickets: I put all of my regular monthly expenses on the same credit card (bills, supermarket, etc), and just pay it off immediately after my purchase so I don't accumulate interests. That way I accumulate a lot of reward points on that same credit card, and I end up having a lot of them that I can use towards the purchase of airline tickets.  When it comes to food, if I'm staying in a place where I can cook, I do so as often as possible from simple recipes I already know well. I don't know how it is in Japan, but in a lot of places buying stuff at the supermarket and cooking is cheaper than eating out, and that way you can splurge on a few really nice dinners out without going out of your budget.

"Use these third party booking sites to book a room at a hotel!" Me, who works reservations in a hotel: Eye twitch     For the record, it's not lost commission or anything like that. It's the extra work and constantly dealing with reps from these sites calling in with broken English to extract promises out of me that they know I can't promise instead of e-mailing us like their company policy says they have to. And that's not to mention the hassle if you get unlucky and your reservation gets cancelled because the site gives the hotel a bad card or if you want specific accommodations (like two beds) because those sites will screw you on that more often than you realize.  Use these sites to find a good hotel, and then book directly with the hotel. If the hotel has a site, it's usually cheaper and better to book on the site than calling. Bonus points if they (like the hotel I work at) have a price match program for those third party sites.

Staying in a hotel in the centre of Tokyo is cheaper per night than renting a house where I live. The most expensive part of our trip was the flights. Three weeks travelling the country with a portable wifi router, travel insurance and JR passes for the two of us for less than 7kAUD including the flights. Went to museums, the Osaka Aquarium, climbed Mt. Takao, visited Kenrokuen in Kanazawa, archery in Hiroshima, went to gaming arcades, ate so many tasty snacks, bought back an extra suitcase of souvenirs and treats. I got a cool purple PS4 controller that you can't get in Australia. Someone once told me that in order to have a good time, you'd need to spend $500 a day?! Nonsense! Pick the big things you want to do before you go, and be smart about what you buy. Just walking and exploring is entertaining. We had some great experiences with locals from picking a direction and walking. Got to meet family of my Japanese friend here in Australia too. Such hospitality!  Once travel restrictions lift we are definitely going again.

Shinkansen view is fine. Nothing spectacular- mostly fields and scattered houses, some towns and cities- if you're lucky you can see Fuji... can also get a glimpse of Himeji if you pass Osaka on to Hiroshima. The newer ones have more tunnel segments since they favor investing the money to just blow through a mountain in a straight line. But overall it's just a pleasant view of fields and scattered homes.  There are fairly full videos out there: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B0FK0Ax-XDQ Can skip through to see the sort of stuff there is to see.  Since the shinkansen favors speed it's of course going to take fairly straight routes in open areas. The slower liner style trains and such up in the mountains have nicer views if it's a matter of views.  But it sounds like your point is you're trying to get somewhere and it's just a matter of choice.  The shinkansen is pleasant for all sorts of reasons. Space, leg room. Where the stations are actually located. How easy it is to use. It's a pleasant trip. Get a nice view. Sneak a little nap in. And you might even feel like you even got a little boost of energy from the trip.  The plane is cheaper. If you go past the distance from Tokyo to Osaka, the plane starts to be faster. It can be a lot faster for the longest of distances. But you have to go through this big hassle of going to the airport, checking in, taking a short little flight, then going from the airport to downtown again. Aside from Fukuoka, the airports are pretty far out. The whole experience of a bunch of short segments is tiring.  The shinkansen you just go from city center to city center. Hop on, and relax in one place for the whole trip. And then you're at the other city center.  Shinkansen (and various ways of using it), bus, and plane all have their pros and cons though, so it's just a matter of what you want.

Because they are often long haul flights. From Europe the average transit time is about 19 hours. On top of that most flights are expensive due the fuel cost and tax that gets added on. Out of the â‚¬650 I paid for my flights 550 went to fuel and tax.

Iâ€™m a retired pensioner from Australia so budget travel is a must . My wife and I we are senior couple so capsule hotels is out . Before we travel to japan we planned ours trip and budget , we travel of season when less tourist and hotels is half price most like APA budgets hotels . We buy JR train rail pass  and mostly used them to travel across in japan  free , in Tokyo  we used mostly JR lines near our hotel . we eat in normal restaurants where mainly found on train station , shopping centres just look at the restaurant with many local peoples eating then you joint them wonâ€™t be expensive and really good quality food , most restaurants have 2 menu Japanese and English . Others than that at every shopping centre ground floor is super market where you can buy take away food and they are many to choose , many of them are freshly cook in front of you , salads or others veggie, fruits , mind you fruits are expensive in japan . Normally ours 3 weeks in Japan including return air fare to Australia Melbourne or Sydney , Jr rail pass , hotels , foods , souvenir total cost about $7000-8000 Australia dollars ( 3000 -4000 English pound ) for a couples , much cheaper than holiday than most country we travel . Japan has becomes ours favourite destination for Holliday . Hopefully we can comeback soon when the pandemic ends .

i travelled to japan 22 times... usually i stay there for 3 to 4 weeks. 1st time i went i spent around 7000 dollars...now as im used to it i spend an average of 3300 dollars. the thing is that you need to experience it couple of times till you find your sweet spot. the most expensive stuff i found are shopping (dont go near expensive brands as theyre much more expensive than europe or middle east). alternatively, use their brands as they are really really good. especially beauty stuff and food. second, taxis (avoid them as much as possible). third use jr pass ONLY if youre travelling to many long range cities (usually 3 or more). forth, try to avoid hotels at the HEART of the city centre as it gets much cheaper as you go further (there are many nice hotels with cheaper fares). fifth, for the bullet trains (shinkansen), do not use green cars as they are way expensive. sixth, there are much cheaper stuff in asakusa jump shops than ordinary shops. make sure to visit them first. seventh, pre book your activites as they are slightly cheaper. eighth, japan tends to be cheaper as you go away from tokyo or osaka. for example hokkaido is cheaper than tokyo. these are the tips i got in top of my head so far. extra: if you like hiking and stuff, visit explore-shareDOTcom. their rates are much cheaper.

That is a real option, and it will make the total cost of food go down because you can buy that 10kg of meat for barely anything per kg, because there are so many people. My de-facto cheapo strategy when I was living in Tokyo was to head to any of the numerous 'Yayoi Ken' restaurants and order the cheapest 'ichiju sansai', a set meal (which is either grilled miso mackerel or deep fried chicken) with unlimited top ups (it's self service, so don't feel shy) of plain, white rice. I would basically fast till as long as I can till about 3-4 pm (there was once I hit a 6 pm record, but it was the summer and I did nothing but hang out at Tower Records listening to records) and head to Yayoiken and eat 6 bowls of rice or something. It's immensely fulfilling for a mere 590 yen. The meal will last you an entire day. Comes with free cold unlimited green tea, pickles and miso soup too. It gets pretty packed during rush hours, but at other times, you can sit there as long as you wish without anyone bothering you, which basically means you can eat as much rice as you like. Some of these branches (like the one in Ginza, several in Shinjuku) are open 24 hours!!!!! That's insanely awesome!!! : )

If you REALLY want to save money on travelling in Japan, you forgot the most important method: Hitchhiking. It might seem a bit weird, but it is SUPER easy to hitchhike as a foreigner in Japan. A fellow traveller I met whilst in Japan said that he never waited for more than 3 minutes before someone picked him up, and while their english wasn't the best, they were always super nice. In fact: it seems to be that Japanese people are much more likely to pick up a foreigner hitchhiking than they are to pick up Japanese people doing the same.

Also consider grocery stores... their ready to eat meals get cleared out every evening and you can get them for half off (or better). Usually that comes out to 5-6pm. When my friend and I visited a few years ago we accidentally discovered this. You can get some really good and filling food for dirt cheap. If you wanted to, I am confident you could get away with under $10 a day on meals, even if you tend to eat a lot. Of course, you are going to be tempted by all kinds of other stuff too, especially if you are traveling. But if you are a week in and look at your expenses and get a little nervous, you can save yourself a bunch of cash to get back on track.

I spent $600 in two weeks for food, entertainment and gifts (for me). I ate a lot. I paid $400 for the rail pass (totally worth it) and I think I was paying $12 a night in Osaka and and Tokyo.   I went Nara, Hiroshima, Nagasaki, Kyoto (visit many temples, parks). The Naruto theme park  I walked to most places. I only rented I bike once. I don't think I spent a lot for everything I did and ate

Although I went to a few places in Kobe Motomachi in September 2019, I did find a lot of good pricing stores and the Combini like 7/11 were a life and pocket savers since meals are replenished daily due to freshness. I even experienced Osaka and it was purely amazing, and you can still find cheap restaurants that serve amazing tasting food. Knowing how much to spend and the exchange rates helps a lot when budgeting. Love Japan <3

Takoyaki is eaten like a snack in Japan. Osaka is famous for this, but there are little differences from region to region.

Realistically for two weeks youâ€™ll spend anywhere from $2,000-$4,000(US), I was there for a month for the rugby World Cup and spent around $8,500(US). That being said we were going all over the country, I was buying lots of souvenirs for friends and family, and myself, rented Japanese sports cars, the tickets for the games, flights there and home, rail pass, and various experiences. Also you should def stay in a love hotel. A room at the Hilton in Tokyo was like 30-40,000 yen a night and the love hotel was like 8,000-10,000 yen($80-$100) and was well worth it after spending the first two and a half weeks in business hotels lol. If youâ€˜re gonna mainly stay in one major area and only plan on doing a day or two trip to say Kyoto, Hiroshima, Tokyo etc donâ€™t get the rail pass. But if you plan on going to a lot of different places then yeah get the pass.  Also make sure to get the Japan official travel app, itâ€™s free and amazing. Looking forward to my next trip to Japan after they find a vaccine for Covid as my parents will no longer have to rely on me going to the shops and dropping their stuff off at theirs. Nippon ichiban!

I went to Japan in '16. The US dollar was worth 75 cents at that time :/ I spent $1,100 for plane ticket, $900 on 21-day JR Rail pass (got mine last minute) definitely cheaper if you get it months in advance). The train pass was worth it though. I took the bullet train from Tokyo to Kyoto. A one-way ticket was like $250 so that's $500 for a round trip. I spent $200 on a hostel through Airbnb for 2 weeks. I was in Japan for 4 weeks. Stayed the first 2 with a friend. I ended up spending like $6k USD in total for everything! Worth it!

Night buses really are amazing.   The ones in Europe can be pretty uncomfortable and expensive, but we used Cruz del sur in Peru. They were so comfy and cheap plus we didn't waste our days travelling! Definitely a good way to go if you want to save money and time on a short trip.

I visited Japan in 2007 for ten weeks and saved a lot of money by hitchhiking through Hokkaido and Tohoku. I did take trains in Kansai, but Osaka was as far West as I went. I got to meet plenty of interesting people and have some great hospitality stories. I also stayed on farms doing work-exchange, so my entire ten week trip including airfare was under $3000. I even bought a tent and camped out for a few nights at various campgrounds (and one temple). Oh and the ferry from Maizeru to Otaru was quite the experience.

Japan's reputation for being expensive developed in the 80s and 90s when the country was properly pricey compared to the West. But decades-long inflation has kept prices in Japan fairly stable, and the rest of the world's cost of living has exploded dramatically, so Japan has become relatively affordable today. Japan is definitely more cheaper to visit than Western Europe, for example.

Thank you so much for your tips Chris! Me and my best friend finally went to Japan after wanting to go since middle school and we never thought it would be possible. We worked minimum wage only a few hours every week at the time we were saving up to go and going to university full time. However, we saved enough for 2 weeks during May-June to fully enjoy Tokyo, Kyoto and Osaka and still have money left over afterwards!  We bought loads of souvenirs (Harajuku's Takeshia Dori and also Don Quijote had the same souvenirs/gifts super cheap, same for Kyoto and Osaka just go to the more local stores rather then the ones full of tourists).  We tried all kinds of delicious food - local restaurants in the more suburban areas were amazing and also affordable for us broke college students for dinner/lunch. 7-Eleven and the vending machines are you new best friends for food throughout most of the day). I even lost weight, not for starving lol - we ate a lot - but for how healthy/cheap the food was and how much we walked around. The most fun moments we had were the one's we surprisingly spent little money like hikes (Fushimi Inari trail is beautiful once you get past the first 100 tori gates gates of tourism traffic hell) and just wandering around the streets/parks of Japan (definitely recommend the extra yen for the Sanso's garden at Arashiyama, one of the most peaceful walks I've had in my life and you can see the entire Arashiyama bamboo grove from there; also Hello Kitty world was incredibly fun too at least for me and I say the price for the ticket was worth it and seeing the Parade and exploring the town the theme park is at afterwards is awesome too). If you're from the US (my bff is) the dollar is amazing but if you're from Canada like myself everything is about the same price as it is here - sometimes cheaper!! Definitely saved money by buying lunch/snacks at convenience stores, Airbnb (couldn't try out the capsule hotel but plan to next time), and going to the "free" tourist traps or choosing them wisely hehe. We didn't get the JR pass since we figured it would be cheaper for us to get the regular Pasmo card for where we were going those 2 weeks and just bought the tickets to Kyoto and Osaka separately; if you're going all the way to Hiroshima or further areas then JR is a good investment. Also book the flights early and you'll get so much cheaper discounts (remember to delete cookies from your browser as the websites catch them and raise flight prices)! Definitely want to go back soon now that I know it's possible :) (This is so long I'm sorry ;;)

4 years ago my ex-girlfriend and I spent 3 months travelling around Japan. We did it very low budget. We hitchhiked everywhere. It turned out Japanese people loved to have us in their car. They were very nice in general. It was hard to have a conversation though, as they hardly understood English and we din't speak Japanese. But guess what? If you got your hands to gesture with and a friendly smile you don't really need to speak the same language. We had a small 2-person tent with us in our backpacks. We camped in forests, city parks and... well... anywhere really. It was wonderful, and we never felt unsafe. Japan is the safest place in the world. Another great thing: Japan had many (very clean) public toilets, which offered a way to wash ourselves in the morning. We ate a lot of onigiri from the convenience stores. We sometimes ate at the Japanese fast food places like Matsui. Of our 3 months we spent 1 month in Tokyo, volunteering at a hostel. We had to do the beds and clean the place for 4 hours a day, 5 days a week. In return they gave us free accommodation and free lunch. We also spent a couple of weeks volunteering for an oyster farmer in Kumihama Bay. In return he gave us free accommodation and 3 excellent meals a day. They were a lovely family. If I have to guess what our average spendings were, I would say not even 5 euros a day. (Not including flights.) It does include entrance fees to a couple of museums (like the ones about the atomic bombs in Nagasaki and Hiroshima). It also includes a nicer meal every now and then, like sushi. And it includes some unforgettable nights at karaoke places and a few refreshing onsen visits. Sure, we did our trip in Japan on a low low low budget, but thanks to our hitchhiking we met hunderds of Japanese people. We spent our nights in our tent often surrounded by nature. We spent 1 month in one of the most expensive cities in the world, Tokyo. If we hadn't travelled the way we did it, we would have spent our entire budget after two weeks. Now we got to spent 3 months in that great country - AND it made our experience a whole lot better! I hope my little story inspires others who also don't have a lot of budget, but who want to see Japan badly, to go there anyway. :-)

You, I like you. This is the way I would prefer to do it, too. I live in the Nederlands now, and there was a time when I had to leave my current acomodation, but failed to secure a new one. I changed provinces, got myself a job, but failed to get a room. So I deposited most of my stuff with friends, bought myself a hammock, sleeping bag, and additional survival stuff as I went on, learning from my mistakes. I worked mixed hours, it was not always busy enough to keep us around full time, but I worked plenty. They had cameras in bicycle shed, so no one tried to steal my stuff while I was at work. I charged my phone and 3DS there, I went to the gym almost every day to take showers, I used friends or dedicated establishments for laundry, stayed in KFC if I wanted internet, and slept in parks, forests, on the beach, basically whenever, and would cycle everywhere or take trains. I spend 7 months living this way, and I was healthy like a bull - not even a cold even if I stood shirtless in rain at 5am, and because I was on the move all the time and used the gym so often I got ridiculously buff and ripped, and saved up like 2k euro in the process lol.

Wow! You're in front of Sendai train station. I love Sendai and your comments. I was in Tokyo & stayed at capsule hotel, 9H, in Shinjuku at $27 USD/night. Another great option in Tokyo and Kyoto is the hostel Imano. I stayed in the Imano Kyoto for 7 days for $430 USD for 2 people. Spotless, wonderful top shelf toiletries, great staff, comfy beds. Cheap food? Good food? Cheap, good food? Aeon, the Japanese version of Prisunic or Target. Most of them have food courts and/or extensive deli areas. I've eaten better sushi from Aeon ($3-6 USD &a enough to share) than many pricey US sushi places. Also great snacks at Aeon...although, how can you miss with DonKee (Don Quixote), Seria, 100Â¥, or my all-time favorite, Daiso. These put US dollar stores to shame. I stock up on housewares, gifts and seasonal items at Daiso. Very high quality. DonKee is more expensive, but steeply discounted, like an Armani down jacket for $60USD. Finally, the Suica card is a reloadable fare card for local buses, trains, subway. Indispensable.

I traveled to Japan a couple years ago and did it for around 4000USD (that includes my flight which was roundtrip 1000USD from the US). I actually used AirBNB for my boarding option as I don't like hostels or public spaces. I spent about $30 a night for a apartment in Oyama when I was in Tokyo and around the same for an apartment in Osaka in Shin-Osaka which factored out to being not all that much for two weeks in Japan since both AirBNB locations had a discount for stays longer than four nights.  I DID spend out for the JR pass and if you want to get somewhere fast, I think it's well worth the money. As I was able to take the Shinkansen between Tokyo and Osaka in three hours and then I could take the shinkansen (normally about 1500 yen a ticket to do it that way) from Osaka to Kyoto and get there in about 15 minutes which was great considering I spent about three days going from Osaka to Kyoto and it was also easier for travel to Himeji, Nara, and other surrounding areas. So in my personal opinion for comfort and convenience I think the JR pass is well worth the expense especially outside of Tokyo where you might get stuck using subway lines which the JR doesn't cover.   I don't think there really a way to budget temples and sites. I think that's just going to end up costing what it costs, but spending out the yen to see castles and temples is well worth it. Honestly, I think I spent out more on sightseeing then I did on food. I'm partial to grocery stores and combinis and if you AirBNB you could find a location directly in front of a store like I did which meant quick cheap food was literally five minutes away.  I spend so much time telling my friends Japan is NOT as expensive as they think but they never seem to believe me. I have friends that want to save up 10000USD or more and I tell them honestly, it's not that expensive but...what are you going to do?

1. "cheapest long-haul destination" I don't know how this could possibly have been imagined into being. Cheapest 'high-end' destination, maybe, but far from the cheapest overall. Cambodia as example is still long-haul for Europeans/Americans and is markedly cheaper in all respects.  South Africa, where I was born and have lived my entire life besides spending ~52 days in Japan and ~10 days in Namibia (and ~2 days in Dubai's airport for transfers), is also markedly cheaper in general.  14GBP for a hostel in Asakusa/Ueno is equivalent to R262 (South African) by today's exchange rate.  At the time your video was made, hostel stays in Cape Town would cost you from R175 for shared dorm style. 'Cat and Moose Backpackers' is an example.  49GBP for a hotel room is ~R920. Hotel rooms of equivalent quality here start from around R500 in the heart of the city.  2. Cost comparison of rail pass, overnight busses etc  Overnight busses also have the additional cost of having to find separate bathing facilities and make use of coin lockers (or having a travel companion watch the luggage...) as opposed to being able to make use of your hotel room's or hostel's bathing facilities for what may well be free (many hostels/backpackers use coin-operated showers). In some cases, laundry will also either be free or so inexpensive as to be basically-free, with the additional benefit of access to tumble-drying facilities in many places. Else, you've either got to tote around a lot more clothing unnecessarily, or go about potentially being smelly (and Westerners tend to smell a lot more and more pronouncedly to Japanese people than other Japanese people do) and sticky from sweat+humidity depending on when, where and how you're traveling.  A night bus also doesn't afford you the luxury of leaving your luggage in your room during daytime excursions, so you've once again either got to find and make use of coin locker facilities, or tote your luggage around with you everywhere you go...  It is, definitely, a great option if you're specifically planning on changing location between Tokyo and Kyoto as example though, since you can 'skip' an evening's accommodation in a hotel where you showered in the morning and did things in the area during the day where toting your luggage didn't matter as much (post check-out from the hotel), then check in at your next destination's hotel to drop your luggage off not too long after arrival the next morning.  Some business hotels (and other 'regular' hotels) include a breakfast buffet or a pre-determined meal for the price thouogh; Wingport Hotel in Nagasaki (very close to the main train station) is/was an example of this. You could thus effectively cut 1,000jpy or more out of your daily meal requirements by having breakfast there, as opposed to having to buy something from a convenience store or finding a place to eat where time might get taken up unnecessarily by having to wait for your meal to be prepared off a menu.  A JR Pass also allows you to easily and quickly visit many disparate locations which could very quickly rack up on your travel expenses otherwise. For my trip with the 21-day and 14-day passes I had, if I had to have bought tickets individually for the places I could reach with the passes instead it would have quickly cost me at least 50% more than my passes cost me for the local trips (factoring in the bullet trains' cost.  3. 'eating on the cheap' I had a few different of Yoshinoya's meals, including beef bowls and their liver and cabbage bowl.  For the price, R46 by current exchange rates (350jpy), you can get a larger meal from a KFC or Burger King (or similar) here in South Africa. Yes, it's not going to be as 'home meal' in appeal, but it's going to be a more substantial meal which won't leave you feeling as-hungry for the price.  Many business hotels in Japan have free-to-rent ('rent' because you've got to go collect it from reception and take it back to them after) cooking utensils and kitchenware. This can allow you to prepare your own lunch if you're not specifically aiming to try out a wide variety of Japanese meals (meals, not snacks). Something which can also save you huge amounts of money, since you can get rice for extremely little and dry, it's compact and lightweight for what it cooks to if you buy a 1kg bag and don't use up all of it 'at once'.  The izakaya option for places with nomi/tabihoudai is great though. If you don't travel alone, in which case... not so great.  As for the onigiri and 'bento packs', something a lot of people don't know is many (and I mean but many) of the convenience stores through the country will 'rotate out' their old stock of fresh foods like these, and in the process of doing so mark down at progressively greater rates the 'old' stock of fresh food items.  A tuna onigiri which could normally cost 180jpy as example can easily be had for as little as 70jpy if you come in just before the next batch of stock is meant to go on the shelves. There's nothing wrong with it, it's still entirely fresh, it just needs to get off the shelves for the new stock...  That said, if you're just going to have plain 100jpy onigiri, just get some nori and rice and prepare your own in your hotel... then you can not only have them substantially cheaper, but also much more interesting/tastier. Just practise making them at home before going over. That, or to make things easier, get a partitioned lunchbox and prepare yourself meals into that instead.  Beer from vending machines can sometimes be had for 150jpy or less for 500ml. Vending-machine hunting for bargains should be part of every visitor's activities; if you're passing a vending machine, at least give its prices for something you'd get a glance if you either want that then, or will be coming back by it later.

I would like to just say that for long term stay (More than a week or two) the cost of your board increases exponentially in any of the noted options. I stayed in Japan for around 3000 dollars for 1.5 months, and I paid about 1000 dollars for a 1 room apartment during that time period (Which comes down to about 22 dollars a day), and it was a proper room, instead of a capsule or dormitory with bunk beds. Also managed to live for that 1.5 months for 2000 dollars, went to Kyoto, stopped at a cheap Ryokan, went to disneyland, and did all sorts of things with that small budget (Though it would've been nice to have more money, as I didn't quite reach all the places I want to go to).  I stayed with a company called "Sakura House", the apartment building itself wasn't exactly pretty, and the room wasn't anything exceptional either, but it had all the necessities (And a bath as well) and was cheap.

No. Just get an IC card like pasmo or suica. 72 hour passes are a little more restrictive (they don't work on all lines), but should usually save you money. If it's just you for a week, then it's probably not worth the bother. You have to learn what lines it works on, design your itinerary to be efficient, and may have to walk out of your way at times to go to a station that accepts it..A lot of trouble for maybe 10-20 USD in savings over a week for just you. But if it's a family of 5 for 3 weeks, it might add up to 200 USD in savings.

Shinkansen is by far the most comfortable. Also by far the easiest. And you pay for it.  There are pros and cons to night buses, flying and shinkansen (JR pass, pay as you go Nozomi or platt kodama). If you're a tourist with time and money, shinkansen is usually the best overall option. The exception being very long plane routes such as Osaka to Sapporo. If you take a plane or a bus, you feel like you've traveled. That's not the case with the shinkansen. There's almost no wear and tear on you from the trip. Frankly, with a little luck you can get a good nap in and end up more rested. So even though it costs more and shinkansen only operate during daylight hours (ie, useful touring time), it leaves you in much better condition and so I prefer it. But.. expensive.

For food:  In the morning, skip the big breakfast and just go all out with a previously hard boiled egg (you boil yourself the night before) and a good cup of coffee. Feel free to add a rice ball to make the fullness last longer. I don't know the cost of a single piece of fresh egg in the supermarket, but it can't be more than 30 Yen. A good cup of coffee can be one of them instant coffees or ready to brew ones from convenience stores. You can buy in bulk and one cup shouldn't cost more than 100 yen. One rice ball can cost up to 150 yen. So, you have yourself a power breakfast at less than 300 yen.    Then, just make do with a really heavy lunch at around 1 PM or so. Splurge on lunch, probably 1000 yen if you're into big yet reasonably priced meals that's good for two. For context, the famous Ichiran 5 at Ichiran Ramen costs 1500 yen if I recall plus one free ramen refill. That pretty good until the next day if you eat past 2 pm.   If you get hungry past 6, buy yourself a 350 yen meal at 7-11, FamilyMart, or Lawson, or during the evening sale at Don Quijote's food floor where every food is either 50% off or buy 1 take 1.   That's a max 1500 yen per day in Japan or about 500 yen per meal per person which is quite a lot for most people. If you're not really a big eater, you can get that down to 1000 yen or so. In dollars, 1500 Yen is like $15.00 You get to fill your belly at $15.00 a day. If you're a big guy or girl, and you're used to spending upwards of $20 per day on food, you will not be hungry anywhere in Japan.    For travel, I don't really recommend the JR passes unless you're going to be literally only using JR lines. The really good places in Tokyo, Osaka, and Sapporo often make use of Subways which the passes don't work with. Not to mention the amount of walking you'll be doing in some of them will make you want to spend a bit more for subways anyway. If you don't mind walking, then you can make the JR passes work wonders, especially in Tokyo and Osaka and their respective surrounding cities. If you're staying for ten days minimum, and you're going to change prefectures halfway (i.e. Tokyo to Osaka), then perhaps the bullet train pass can work. Plus points if you use the bullet train again, and again, and again within the same travel week.    For most tourist, they only use the bullet train once per week if they ever do since each prefecture has a lot of places to visit.

I just came back from Japan. I stayed there for 16 days, only hostels and capsules. To give a pretty good example, the best capsule hotel was in Kobe, right at the station and I was able to book a night for 1700 yen (about a month before I went) instead of 3000 that was the standard price. The hostels were about 1500 - 2000 per night, depending on the area. In Kyoto and Osaka it was a bit cheaper, the most expensive one was in Tokyo. I also stayed in Hamamachutso and Akihabara for the same price more on less. Skipped the JR pass and travel with the night buses (about 70 euros for a round trip) and that way I also skipped a couple of night at a hostel. I chose all the hostel locations to be in walking distance (about 30 mins) from where I wanted to go, in order to save on buses and metro. Unfortunately due to  circumstances I had to ride more buses and metro than I thought (rain, typhoon, phone battery dying), but my mentality was correct. For food I realized that the cheap options (like 7eleven) are only a bit cheaper than ramen or small restaurants, so I ate mostly at them, occasionally cup noodles and sushi. Every time I found a big super market, the food and drinks were cheaper than the compini so I took advantage of that. For entertainment there is a ton of free things to do in Japan. Visiting temple, mountains, almost everywhere there was something free. Of course I had to pay for the most well known attractions (like golden pavilion) but even if I didnt visit those, I would still be feeling fulfilled.   With some careful planing, and maybe a bit of inconvenience you can still experience the full Japan package on a budget. I am Greek btw, so if I could do it, everyone can

Travel tip: in Tokyo airbnb is way cheaper that booking. For the same price you can stay in a â€œmore or less okâ€ apartment or not so ok hostel/hotel. In Kyoto itâ€™s possible to get good deals on booking while on airbnd not so much. Tokyo has really cheap public transport card (for foreigners), in Kyoto is best to rent a bike. It can be costly to get to small towns in Japan- we took a bus from shimoda to local beach and paid around 8eu for a 20min bus ride (if I remember correctly in Tokyo three day train pass cost 15eu).

When I visited Japan (It was a while ago I'll give you...) I found the best way to save money was simply to NOT go to the biggest brightest places :) Builders/Workers cafe's were better in may cases than the tourist places, having food from a Lawsons/7'11 was just as good as room service, shop around! Always! Found a cheap Ryokan (Traditional Inn) which was near Ueno park and a little dated but perfectly charming, save money by not drinking a lot, drinking seemed to be the most expensive thing to do so, keep it to a few nights and if you need to have a drink or seven, go buy them from the convenience stalls and drink at the hotel or while sat in a park etc. Oh and JR RAIL PASS! :D

Ginger Kubicz I went to Japan recently and stayed in capsule hotels for 12 days. The total accommodation cost is around Â¥ 37,860 (more or less $355), not including Â¥200 tax/day. Capsule hotels are really comfortable and clean, so if youâ€™re planning to save money I think it is one of the best way to go. Also, if you only plan on visiting Tokyo, you can save a lot of money with your food. Out of all the three cities I visited (Osaka, Kyoto, and Tokyo), I spent the least in Tokyo. Thereâ€™s a lot of small restaurants that have cheap menu but still serve clean and good food. Honestly, you canâ€™t go wrong with food in Japan! Having gone to Japan earlier this summer, I wholeheartedly second his recommendation of getting a Japan Rail Pass, it makes life so much easier and saves on the taxis and trouble of buying train tickets, although you'll still have to figure out which line to take and where to go to reach said line. You just show your pass at the entrance ways to the platforms and off you go, simple as that.   I also second his recommendation of staying in Ueno, that's where I stayed and I thought that it was fairly centrally located for the Tokyo area.There's lots to see and do in the immediate area, plenty of restaurants all around both inside and outside the train station there. It's also really close to Akihabara as well as Harajuku and if you're into Pokemon, the Pokemon Cafe isn't all that far from there either.

Riceball01 would you be able to inbox me, I need some help planning out a trip to Japan
Â @NewYork4Life12Â  Not sure how to do that but I'd be happy to help however I can.

Riceball01 I really appreciate it. I live in the states, and I want to take my friend to Japan, she always wanted to go there as well as me. I just wanted to know how much I would need to save up. Iâ€™ll probably be in Tokyo for the majority of the trip but I may want to visit Hiroshima. I was thinking with airfare being 2,100 round trip for both of us, and hotel, sightseeing for a week & a half, I was thinking 15K. What do you think?

Â @NewYork4Life12Â  Well, I didn't pay for the trip all out of pocket myself, had help from my in-laws and my wife's ex, but I think that 15K should be more than enough. Your main expenses are hotel and airfare, food isn't too bad , and most sightseeing/tours don't cost a whole lot either particularly if you don't mind walking tours.   I'd recommend getting a Japan Rail Pass, this makes taking trains so much easier and you'll need to take the train to get from one part of Tokyo to another. I'd also be sure to set aside cash/money for taxi fare, you'll need to take the cab for some of the further parts of wherever  you're staying that might be too close to bother with taking a train.   Speaking of trains, all of the platforms have signs in English and inside the trains they'll have electronic signs above the doors that will alternate between Japanese and English and it will announce each stop in Japanese and English.This makes taking trains in Japan really easy once you figure out which train you need to take and which platform it's at.   One other thing I'd recommend is if your cell plan doesn't include roaming data for free or if your hotel doesn't provide with a phone to borrow then I'd get a Japanese SIM card for your phone when you get there.  Having data will allow you to look up train schedules, find places to eat and comes in very handy with taxis. Even when the driver doesn't speak English all you have to do is bring up where you want to go on Google Maps and show your driver your phone.

"A lot" is maybe stretching it a bit, but it is cheaper. I heard a rumour that the supermarket sushi is often better than conveyor sushi - can't confirm that, but I had (iirc) octopus rice from a supermarket once and it was okay. On the other hand, where else are you gonna get your Family Chicken? For the non-English speakers who can't tell the difference: both of them sell packaged food, junk food, beverages, alcohol and some basic necessities like stationery and tissue paper. However, supermarkets are much bigger and also sell ingredients for cooking - such as fresh (raw) fruit, vegetables and meat - which convenience stores usually don't.

When the value of the Yen drops, it makes things made in Japan cheaper to people who live outside Japan.  That means more people will travel to Japan, or will buy things made in Japan, because it gets less expensive for them.  That means more business for people who live in Japan, even though things that are made in Japan don't cost any more for the Japanese people themselves.  The only bad part is that goods that are imported to Japan get more expensive for Japanese people.  So for instance, if the value of the Yen drops, foreigners will be able to buy more Japanese whiskey, Japanese people will be able to buy the same amount of Japanese whiskey, but Japanese people will be able to buy less Scotch whiskey.

Currently, a large amount of rice is produced every year in Fukushima, Japan's radiation-exposed area, but it can never be sold to Japanese consumers. After purchasing a large amount of rice from the Japanese government, the rice from Fukushima was secretly supplied in large quantities through hotels, restaurants, and many catering establishments that are frequented by tourists, and is now being consumed by tourists. Perhaps it is very likely that the rice you bought at a tourist resort restaurant in Japan was contaminated with radioactivity produced in Fukushima.

My partner and I lived in Japan for 4 years, and whenever we were travelling, we almost always used Business Hotels. The rooms tend to be small, but they're clean and comfortable, a perfectly good place to rest your head at night, and much cheaper than regular hotels, but with the quiet and privacy you won't get a hostel.  And Japanese fast food is brilliant, so much better and more satisfying than McDonalds. Along with the donburi (rice bowls) I was a huge fan of the Doutor coffee chain coffee & sandwich lunch set for ~Â¥400.

It is and I can also highly recommend getting one, it makes things so much easier. You can use them in pretty much every train and bus in Greater Tokyo, you can even go to Yokohama from Tokyo with an IC card if you want to, just not with Shinkansen I think. Also limited express, express and green car aren't included so for example if you fly to Narita and want to use NEX, you have to buy a separate ticket. Suica and Pasmo can be used in most other cities too for example Kansai area (Osaka, Kyoto etc.) but you cannot go from Tokyo to Kansai with them because the area between them isn't included. You can check the coverage map online if you decide to go away from Greater Tokyo. Note that Tokyo has 3 major train companies: JR (for example Yamanote circle line), Tokyo Metro (the blue M logo, almost everywhere, hence my favourite) and Toei which isn't that big. You can use them all but if you have to change train to get to your destination and the next train is different company than the first one, there will be a small extra fee so if you want to save some money and if it's possible, try to plan your routes so that you only have to use one company on a single trip. Downloading a train line map of Tokyo to your phone helps a lot and you could always use hyperdia.com too to plan as long as there is an internet connection. Since I'm making so many recommendations already, I must say one more. Maps.me, it's available free for Android, it's basically an offline map app where you can download maps of entire areas, mark places you wish to visit and use it without internet to show where you are, navigate etc. for free because GPS doesn't cost anything. Saves the hassle of having a big paper map with you. I've used it in Japan, Thailand, Greece and UAE among others and it has saved me quite a few times already ðŸ˜‚

I ended up getting a 5k loan to travel to japan with around 5k already saved up to go there. The trick is to use companies like AIRBNB and have a solid idea of where you are going and what you are going to do. To be honest if you don't plan on learning any Japanese I would advise not to go until you at least know the basics. If you don't understand anything it becomes frustrating for you and whoever you are trying to talk to. Even the basic knowledge of language goes a long way and Japanese people be delighted in general to find out you know the basics of the language and will bend backwards to help you out. Can't wait to go back.

JesseReset, go. I never planned to, but started going in the aftermath of 3/11 on short term mission trips. I fell in Love with the people and the culture. You can monitor cheap flights on Google Flights, and stay in a nice hostel or capsule hotel. Cheap eats at supermarket deli sections, great bakeries, and amazingly great coffee at the 7-11. Last time I went (12/19) my flight was $635 rt, but it's cheaper to fly into Haneda, which is also much closer to Tokyo if you're trying to make train connections.

Don't. While not knowing a language may seem very daunting, travelling is definitely worth it.  You wouldn't believe how many people know English around tourist towns. When I was in India, I had people in hotels and stores walk up to me to practice their English. However, it definitely doesn't hurt picking up a few phrases. Please and Thank You go a long way in other places. However, if you still feel a bit unsure about it, I know my sister learns a lot from the Duolingo app. You don't need to be fluent to have a fun time, and it's the little mishaps that sometimes make the greatest stories looking back on.

Just get an airbnb. You'll get the best value in terms of cost to privacy + living space and amenities. I went to Japan last year (2018) and paid $900 for an airbnb for 2 entire weeks. That's $64/night. More importantly, I went with a friend, which means we both stayed at the place. The price didn't change. In other words it was actaully $32/night per person. EXTREMELY cheap. The place was a private apartment, was relatively spacious (my friend and I were quite comfortable and had no complaints) had a host of amenities that a typical hostess/hotel/capsule hotel wouldn't have, had free wifi, free pocket wifi for when we left the apartment meaning we were always connected even when our cell phones wouldn't connect to roaming. We had a large screen TV. We weren't exactly in the heart of Tokyo but close enough to commute to anywhere in Tokyo quite quickly. Furthermore, the host was super helpful and would quickly respond to any questions about either the room, or the city we might have. You won't get that with any other place. There's no competing with the value you get from renting out someone's private apartment and dealing with a good host. There just isn't. Quite frankly I can't imagine any reason to NOT get an airbnb. It's surprising the video doesn't mention airbnb as an option. I have no idea why I would want to stay in a shitty hostell or capsule hotel when I can have an entire private apartment for a similar cost.

You know, every J-vlogger says Japan is dirt cheap to live in.  But when I watch the videos, what people say blatantly contradicts the way the Japanese live.  For all their high-tech toilets and video games, other modern conveniences that we in the West take for granted are conspicuously missing in Japan: clothes dryers, dishwashers, central air conditioning, water heaters, etc.  Whole families have to share bath water for Gosh sakes!!!  That's disgusting!!!  The lowest caste member in the family comes out of the bath dirtier and smellier than when they went in!!!  And when it's cold, people sit snuggled around low tables with "cold tattoos" inside them, instead of, you know, turning up the thermostat.  Everyone drives itty-bitty cars, but okay, that's probably due to the narrow streets and lack of parking.      BTW, I'm not hating on you -- I'm a subscriber and I love your vids :-)   I'm just pointing out what I see as an obvious contradiction between what J-vloggers say and what I'm seeing...  A couple years ago, I asked a similar question on that Aussie bloke's channel.  I wasn't rude or anything -- I just asked matter-of-factly like here.  The guy ripped me a new one like I hit a nerve or something.  Anyone else here besides me see any elephants in the living rooms of Japan regarding the cost of energy????

And you can just recharge the Suica other IC Card at any convenient store instead of buying at ticket machines. JR pass is not always cheaper. I saved about $60 using IC card only instead of buying a JR pass, and it opened up so many faster and easier routes to go between places.

I should make a video about life in the MInato ward in Tokyo, and the cost of living  here. A 3LDK apartment, $8500 per month, plus another $700 in association fees, plus another $500 per month for a parking spot. Utilities, like gas, electricity, internet, and water, are about $400 per month. Car ownership? Figure $2000 per year for inspection, registration, road tax, and insurance. Gas is about $7 per gallon, getting halfway across the city will run about $20 in tolls. As for food, my usual rule-of-thumb computation is think about what I would pay for a steak, a potato, or container of milk in America, and multiply by 4.5 Have kids? Japanese schools suck,  but a good international school is some $40,000 per year, per kid, for tuition, activities, and transportation. Taxes? No matter what your income, you'll pay at least some income tax, at least $2000 per year in residency tax, and at least $2500 per year for the national healthcare plan. You get a large write off for kids, and kids get free medical treatment up to the age of 15, but what you save in healthcare and taxes is more than offset by the cost of food, which, in Japan, is also taxed.

My mom, sister and I stayed in Tokyo for four days with around Â¥120,000 total in our pockets (doesnâ€™t include lodging and flight). We got home with probably 6 months supply of snacks and candy, some anime merchandise, a single Â¥10,000 bill and some loose change. Ueno is indeed the cheapest district for lodging but we probably overspent, having actually rented an apartment and all. We lived off of walking for hours, eating ramen and sushi throughout the day and cooking our own breakfast (or taking a few discounted onigiri in the convenience store). Although we did eat at some restaurants, but Iâ€™m not sure if those were the cheap or relatively pricier ones.  The bullet trains are said to be expensive too, but really youâ€™ll only need them if you want to go to other prefectures (or if you want to travel fast as fq as if youâ€™re always running late to a meeting.) Heck, my cousin who went to visit us for no reason went to Shibuya all the way from SHIZUOKA using the SUBWAY TRAINS.

Kia Ora, Iâ€™m from New Zealand, and Iâ€™m planning to go for a month with a friend in January in 2020. I know Japan is expensive, so I want heaps of time to save, so I have found out that my flights will cost $1,500 NZD including return. But I want to know if 5k is enough (including flight money) for spending, accommodation, transport as me and my friend will be splitting the transport and accommodation cost together as well, or should I save more? As we both agreed to save a total of 5k each for the whole trip
Guess not
Megan B. Japan is what they are today because of the US occupation.   And the Japanese culture of course.

Anyway, I'll work in USD and you can convert back to NZD if it's convenient for you... currently it's about 1500 NZD to 1000 USD. In SHORT (with explanation to follow), it's 100 USD/day + long range travel + plane. So assuming you'll just be in Tokyo (or JUST Osaka/Kyoto, or JUST some other city), it's 30 x 100 USD + 1000 USD = 4000 USD = 6000 NZD Also, this assumes fairly basic accommodations I'd expect from a month long trip. Is 5000 NZD ENOUGH?  Possibly. But it's not enough to have available... you'll want access to more if needed. Frankly, even though I listed it at 6000 NZD, having another 500 NZD buffer minimum would be wise.  Some things to keep in mind: You're planning your trip very far in advance. I think you can do better than 1000 USD. Although I'm coming from a bigger hub, the distance is approximately the same. And while 1000 USD is a standard (summer) price, I can get it for less than half that if I check prices often. Even if you can't do that well, 1000 USD seems high for a trip planned this far in advance. Mind you I'm not really sure how they charge flights when you're going south to north hemisphere... but I still think that whatever price you think is normal with your research so far, that you can do better than that with regular price checking.  AirBnB is one of the best options, but it's going through a bit of a legal battle in Japan right now. How this turns out can heavily affect what sort of stuff you'll be able to get at a reasonable price. But with the two of you, you can rent out a private room in some hostels or get a room at a business hotel and it's not too bad. But if AirBnB can get things back in order you can do better for cheaper. Probably average 25-50 USD/night per person... but 20-40 USD outside Tokyo. AirBnB can get you better stuff for the low-mid end of that.  Transportation within Japan is very expensive. Like, within the cities, there are special tickets and while not cheap, they're still decent compared to a lot of other cities. BUT when you try to go far away to other cities, the price goes way up. Staying there a month it's likely you'd want to go to other places. This can get expensive. Bus is a reasonable option, and a night bus saves you paying for a night (but probably means you won't sleep, >__<). Rail pass is expensive... really, this cost is so variable that that is why I keep it separated from the other stuff.  AND then, back to the standard 100 USD/day recommendation.  This assumes 50 USD for basic lodging, BASIC food, transportation and wi-fi. And then 50 USD wiggle room to spend to upgrade your lodging or food, or have fun. So if you're spending much above 30 USD/day on lodging, it's either coming out of your fun fund, or you need to save up more. Food is just for basic fast food style stuff... upgrading past that is taking from the 50 USD.  And in general, it should average out. Touristy temple days and park days that cost almost nothing average out with shopping and expensive meals and it should come out to around 80-120 USD/day for a fun, vacation sort of trip where you can spend fairly freely but not extravagantly. That said, your personal tastes affect the total a lot too. If you're content with museums, parks, and shrines... 60 USD/day is possible.  But expensive tastes every day could run 120-200+ USD/day.  And that is an important point. Japan is a place where there is what amounts to the 1 USD option, the 3 USD, the 10 USD option and the 100 USD option for almost everything... you can get by fairly reasonably... or you can spend a fortune in a single day. You have to know you.

Basically tattoos are a bit of a taboo over there just as they are associated with the yakuza and they are basically the only Japanese people that have them. I think most people realise tattoos donâ€™t have the same connotations around the world so you get a bit of a free pass as a foreigner.Having travelled through Japan with someone with tattoos it didnâ€™t seem to pose any real issues on our trip. One thing to note though is that a lot onsen donâ€™t allow tattoos, basically because they donâ€™t want yakuza using it as a place to have meetings (which to my understanding is something that yakuza actually do). You can avoid this by having a private onsen, often available if you are staying at a ryokan, or go to a tattoo friendly onsen which are becoming more common. Anyway have a nice trip, donâ€™t let the tattoo issue put you off coming to Japan itâ€™s really not a big deal :)

Shouldn't be a problem at all, unless you're going to an uber rural corner of Japan.  As you say, musicians + tatoo + rock/punk is very common imagery.  No Japanese is going to be taken off guard by that.  The Tatoo thing is purely about Public baths - they are just saying No for the sake of argument against the Yakuza tatoo history - because disallowing it was a major step in trying to push Yakuza's out of the public.  This happened rather recently, so overturning the practice so soon would lose face for those who fought for it.  All in all,  you're fine.

Just got back from Japan and in Tokyo at least, their were a few Japanese people who had some tasteful tattoos, as well as there were quite a bit more gaijin tourists than I would have expected with sleeves and such. I didnâ€™t see so much of that in Kyoto, Osaka, Nara etc. so, I think Tokyo is a bit more progressive in its acceptance of tattoos than other places. I got a compliment for my tattoo at the robot restaurant in Shinjuku from one of the staff, which is funny because I was wearing long sleeves the whole trip trying to hide it!
So in other words a two week stay will cost you about 5 to 9 grand US

I went to Japan for 2Â½ weeks in February-March 2015. For 10 nights in a business hotel in Tokyo (between Ueno and Asakusa, as the video mentions) I paid an average of US $62 per night. For 7 nights in a business hotel in Osaka, an easy walk from super-convenient Shin-Osaka Station, I paid an average of $53 per night, including breakfast buffet. Round trip airfare from San Francisco to Narita was $1053, the 14-day Japan Rail Pass was $380, other transportation within Japan totaled $86 (Â¥9930), and I went to Tokyo, Kamakura, Osaka, Kyoto, Nara, Himeji, Takarazuka, Hiroshima, and Itsukushima. I ate a lot of gyÅ«don, curry, ramen, etc., so I ended up spending only $299 (Â¥34,408) on food and drink during those 18 days.

It's valid at JR stations. Which means most of the main skeleton of lines for the country. Private companies then filled in other routes if it was believed to be profitable. That means MOST routes inside major cities are NOT JR, though JR can be used to go most places in Osaka and Tokyo... the other lines just provide more flexibility and sometimes more direct routes. Onomichi is JR. Note that if you don't actually need to go to Tokyo, there are some good regional passes that cover Osaka/Kyoto to Hiroshima, to Fukuoka. Alternatively, the airport is very convenient from Fukuoka, so if you wanted to go somewhere like Okinawa or Sapporo that can't be reached (or at least not easily in case of Sapporo) by train, it may be better to combine a regional pass with some cheap flights, rather than get the full JR pass. Again, depending on what you want to see and do.

It's bad if you don't like things super humid. Additionally, most of the fun stuff of summer will be over, so you're just stuck with the heat/humidity. If your tastes are mostly indoors/air conditioned stuff anyway it may not matter toooo much... but if it's first time, it's not ideal to go then. Flight will also likely be on expensive side. If you can't get other time off from work/school then it can't be helped of course... go when you can. But Oct/Nov/Mar/Apr/May are preferred.

Taxi is pretty much the most expensive in the world. Normal people don't take taxis in Japan. Not usually anyway- if it's raining or summer and you want to get to your date or interview without looking like crap it may be a good idea to take ataxi. A lot of jobs provide travel per diem for their employees... so really the taxi is just providing service at high cost to businessmen.  Is it expensive to party? Well, that, however, depends on you. Like many things in Japan, there are cheap and expensive versions of everything. There are all you can drink places for like 10 USD where you can totally have a good time with some friends. Bar/club cover charges can vary widely. Drinks can be expensive. But I mean, once you get there it's a matter of being cool enough that other people will pay for you.

Knowing more is helpful... language learning is logarithmic... you can see MAAAJOR gains of usefulness with a vocab of 100-200 words... but how much is worth it depends on how long you're going for and how long you have to learn stuff.
