I don't see skateboards even though they would make sense. So I'm not sure of the exact rules for them, especially in super downtown areas. Otherwise... September through the 25th or so will still be reallllly humid. And it's typhoon season so there will probably be a day or two where you'd definitely want to use the train to go anywhere. But yeah, overall should be okay.

Thanks for the reply redfish337, I appreciate. I think I'll take my pennyboard and see how the weather is. In the worst case I will take the subway when it's not rush hour to get around. I just can't stand being packed like sardines in any place :D

It's rarely very packed, especially if you don't just HAVE to go someplace into town at like 7-8:30 AM. Only the commuter trains heading out are all that bad at night since everyone gets off at different times (cuz too much overtime).  Anyway, just a reminder that skateboards aren't common at all here so you bring a lot of attention to yourself. As you approach the downtown districts you should probably pick up your board and walk. I think it'd probably be more useful for someone living a bit further out where the train system isn't as good. If you want to be out late past last train that gives you a bit more reasonable range though.

You have a place to stay for free?  Then maybe 1000 USD + flight + discretionary expenses... depends a lot on your tastes and interests. I would bring at least 2000 USD (and ideally have access to 3000 USD if necessary) but you'd probably float in the 1300-1800 USD range.

You can, it can be expensive but it's definitely a bonus to have you're own transportation.  Also it's legal to sleep in your car in Japan, so if you're really trying to save money you can just camp out of your hire car.

Yes you can. You'll need an international driver's licence, a credit card, and be prepared for slow speed limits and numerous toll roads. It's a whole lot cheaper (unless you're going to camp in your hire car) to just train/fly/bus your way around. I'm still looking into a long road trip there anyway, but it's not like being out on an open road for hours like say here in Australia, or parts of the US.

Also plan your trip as meticuously as you can. Japanese transportation is almost always on time (except in case of natural problems), so you can plan out your entire day and actually stick to it, it's amazing and a luxury. (Except for Peach. Don't trust Peach)

What I used to do, is walk a lot, and I mean A LOT. If the distance was covered by a train, I would still walk if it was a short distance. Around midday my feet would always hurt (my feet easily hurt, but still...). I'm not sure how much money it saved me, but I could also enjoy the scenery while walking.  Plus some cities have bike rental. In Nara there was a super cheap bike rental in the vincinity of the park, and I used it to get to the other side of the city in no time. Plus it's healthier and you get to see the city.

Matsuya is my love <3 it's really cheap and super tasty <3 I think Yoshinoya and Sukiya are slightly more expensive? Still super cheap though.  Also there's something more cheap: the frozen section of konbinis. 100 yen for a frozen pack of chahan (fried rice). If you stay in a hostel with a fridge and microwave or stove, that's an easy and super cheap option. Konbini are my other love <3 The manjuu, onigiri, and karaage <3.  Also they have relatively cheap packaged bread products. I always bought the breads filled with red bean paste (four or five small filled breads for 100 yen), and ate them as a snack while on the go, when I was hungry but in the middle of sight seeing. One bun can be eaten in two bites so it's not that distracting when in public.  Still research beforehand which specialties of which region you want to try, and try them at least once.

I just returned from a four-week trip around Japan. Flights + accommodation (airbnb), we managed a SGD1,100 ($839), and living expenses (food+transport) I managed to thrive under 100,000 yen (around $1000).   FYI transport was nearly half that total because we travelled great distances, between Kansai and Hokuriku, then Gifu, Aichi, and Tokyo. All the cost totaled up to under 1.9k, and we still had a lot of leftover money to buy stuff.

I've been to Japan twice in the past year, and I wish I saw this video! Now I just send this video to friends who are interested in traveling to Japan for their first time. The hotel and lodging situation was very insightful.  It truly is how much YOU are willing to budget.  Both trips, I traveled with 1 other person. First trip, we did the rail pass, and it came out to be worth it, because the JR covered long distance travels (Tokyo to Kyoto) and sub city travel for the 7-day period. Airbnb was worth it, and you make a great point about staying "somewhere interesting".  2nd trip, no JR pass, since we stayed in Tokyo. Might have saved a bit buying a suica card, but we got buy just paying per trip.  We opted out of doing an airbnb, and ended up staying at a hotel, which turned out to be worth it, considering their breakfast buffet was included every morning.
You can find airbnb places from 20 to 40 bucks / night though.

I've tried to coordinate vegetarians visiting Japan few times, and I must say, unless you're willing to prepare extensively, Japan will be a nightmare for vegi.   The reason being is that, simply put, the society doesn't really have any vegetarians, and so they don't sell food catered for those needs.  If you're a vegan, even worse.  For example, of ALL foods sold in those Japanese convenience stores, of the few thousand items they have on shelf, and after running around 5 different locations, the only food I could find for my visiting vegan friend was Vegetable Sticks and Salad.    The only place you can eat out reliably would be Indian restaurants, or some random "hip" "western" influenced restaurants in Tokyo, of which I don't think most people visiting Japan would to too interested in...
Just have meals at the Buddhist temples that accommodate tourists. Those are all 100% vegetarian for religious reasons.

Everyone takes it, but most people aren't comfortable using it.  So in short, English isn't used, but you can rely on it if you're desperate.  In practice, learning 100 words or so will help you a lot, but you can still get by with basically nothing (in which case I still recommend learning courtesy words) if you need to or if it isn't practical to learn anything. If you're 6+ months off for a 10+ day trip, then I would recommend trying to learn how to say 50-100 words, and be able to recognize the meaning of ~30 or so important kanji words. The main tourist districts and areas of major cities and attractions will have English available. As a general rule of thumb- most people can understand basic English, but are not confident to use it.  A small, but significant minority are. This means you can't reliably use English. But, if you're desperate, you can reliably find someone who can help you. As you get out to the countryside the English use will drop off significantly. But people in the countryside are less hurried and more willing to help despite having to go through hoops gesturing and whatnot to communicate. (You can get help in a city like Tokyo, but please try to ask people who don't look busy... they'll feel obligated to help you despite their rush, making the whole situation really uncomfortable). As for gestures... if that's all you have, then sure. But you really should learn basic courtesy words at the very least. You are MUUUCH more equipped with 100 words of vocab than with 0. And the helpfulness of learning more is of course logarithmic. 1000 words... even with no real understanding of grammar, and you can pretty much do anything short of get a job. If you have the time, 1 word a day will put you in very good position by the time you go. If you're just going once for not very long that' overkill and perhaps a waste of time though. You need to make a judgement call on what's worth it.

Are you including flight? If so, it depends on where you're coming from.  The second most important thing is what sort of lodging you need.  You can airbnb a studio apartment for like... $50 each for a decently nice place.  And the third most important thing is where you want to go. Going to multiple far away cities means flights or shinkansen or a railpass (or... god forbid, a bus). This long distance domestic travel adds up fast.  So, it's a tentative yes. But just realize that there's pretty much the $5, $50, and $500 version of basically everything in Japan. If you're rolling in the $5 or $50 slots most of the time, you should be fine. But the high rolling opportunities are there, and will burn through budget fast. And again, travel expenses, if you're including them in the $3500, will vary by person a lot.

redfish337 Thanks for the thorough reply. The $3500 was only for food, activities, and lodging. This was our tentative plan. We're going to fly out of Philadelphia into Tokyo. Stay there for 2-3 days. We were going to get the Japan rail pass to travel from city to city on the bullet train. So from Tokyo to Kyoto to Hiroshima. We'll probably stay 2-3 days at each place. I already accounted for all travel though. I hope that clears some things up. Thanks again for the reply.

In that case, lodging, activities and food for 10 days can be done for $100 per person/day fairly easily which would only take $1000 or so. So a $3500 pace over 10 days would be quite extravagant.  Or not really, if you must insist on using regular hotels rather than airbnb/business hotels/hostels. Lodging is the biggest waste of money... Japan isn't a resort destination- you shouldn't be spending much time at the lodging. That said, if you do have this sort of budget, you can spend on 1-2 nights in a nice ryokan as a splurge lodging. Western hotels are world class, but again, you're not supposed to be sitting in your hotel all day in Japan. =P  Ryokan are at least an experience. If you can keep spending on that down you should be able to spend on pretty much anything else you'd want. Just for reference, NOT INCLUDING flight, I'd budget ~$1600/per person for literally everything else (including rail pass).... and have access to at least $2000 to have some buffer. Most stuff of interest to tourists in Japan really isn't very expensive. That's the "careful with the boring stuff so I can spend on stuff I like" budget. But I mean, if you're intent on spending $3500, that's easy enough too. =P

I don't plan on spending like I'm rich. But I also don't want to pinch pennies. We just want to have a true vacation where we can do whatever we want. Thank you again. You've been a lot of help.

Something that you didn't mention is the Japan Bus Pass! I've been using that while I'm here and it's saved me a good amount of money on the buses. The pass is 12,500 yen for 3 days, or 15,000 for 5 days. It allows you to take any Willer bus you'd like to on the days that you claim. For example, let's say that you're in Kyoto. You want to go to both Osaka and Hiroshima. You can claim one of your bus pass days, take a bus to Osaka early on, explore that day, and hop on a night bus to Hiroshima that night (so long as that bus leaves on the same day, it's considered just one day). The 5 day pass can literally save you hundreds of dollars (and you can also save more on your passes if you decide to only travel mon-thursday). Also the days are not consecutive, so if you only use the bus on, for example, the 3rd of the month, the 10th, and the 17th, that's fine.  If you're going to Japan on a serious budget, I would look into it!

Well, Japan isn't as good as say the USA where almost every place has unlimited soft drinks.  But it applies to a few places. For example, most family restaurants (essentially Japan's take on Denny's... Denny's exists too, but it's almost universally considered worse than all the competition)... have a drink bar with unlimited refills of soda... usually coffee/cappuccino/tea, and juice and occasionally some more exotic things. If you want to drink up, this is actually preferable because there's no time limit (occasionally ones near say, a campus, will post a sign against say, doing schoolwork). You can chat for friends with hours and drink all the cappuccino and melon soda you want.   The all you can eat places tend to have a timer. They will often offer a drink bar with sodas, or pay more for the alcoholic drink option.  Some places like an izakaya I don't think you can specify... you just pay a set amount for the time and it's priced as if you will mostly drink alcohol.

When I was in Japan in 2015, I stayed at business hotels in Tokyo and Osaka. The one in Tokyo was US$62 per night, and the one in Osaka (with breakfast buffet included!) was US$53. Both were very conveniently located for the places I wanted to go.

Japan is expensive

Most Japanese people don't eat very much... so yeah, they can make a profit.  They just have to take a bit of a hit when the foreigners come. =P Unfortunately, since all of those places tend to be time-limited, even we can only do so much damage. Yakiniku grill takes too long... shabu-shabu is preferable since it cooks in a few seconds... kushikatsu is okay.

From the US? It just depends... most people in the US would want to go to some touristy place in the US to vacation. That increases cost.  You go to some plush hotel in Tokyo and it's 500+ USD a night.... fancy izakaya may be 100+ USD per person... etc. You can burn through a lot fast. The advantage of going abroad is that well... the lower class and mundane is still exciting and special. And the advantage of Japan in particular is that it has a relatively high basic standard... cleanliness and safety are paramount, so even staying at some low end place in a  sketchy district to keep the cost down... it's just not going to be that bad. In the US, if you try to go too cheap (and that could still be expensive in a place like SF or NYC...) the place could very well be total %#^$# and you've probably got a pretty good chance to get mugged... forcing you to spend more to stay in a better place and area, and increasing the cost above the super low end stuff of Japan.

If you're trying to keep the cost down, stay at places with showers. Hostels should all have them- airbnb should usually have them. Western style hotels will usually have individual shower/baths, but you'll find that Japanese style accommodation of almost any price range will usually expect you to use an in-house facility in the style of a bath house or onsen.  Bathhouses aren't expensive... but they aren't cheap either. So most people do spend time relaxing rather than just wash off and leave.  I'd suggest having a bathhouse (or preferably, onsen/hotspring) experience- but make it an experience, not your daily routine. If you can spring for a night at a ryokan in a hot spring town, then, IMHO, that's pretty much the only accommodation at least arguably spending a lot on unless you're overflowing with money.. Or even if you have a shower, go try out an onsen someplace. But again, go do it to relax for an hour+ after a long day... not as your daily routine.

If you know what you're doing, you can save some money using day passes. But pretty much everyone should still get a suica. Just don't put a lot of money on it if you know you will mostly be using day passes.

It changes all the time so it's an outdated video as soon as you make it... but for AUD you just convert to cents. So 100 yen = 100 cents = 1 AUD to get you an estimate.  I don't know the actual range for AUD, but right now you get a little less than that, so it's like a 15% upcharge.  So if you see something for 1000 yen, you can convert to 1000 cents, which is 10 AUD. But you have to make a 15% adjustment for the current rate, it's 11.50 AUD.

They're often super hot... dependent on your luck rather than the weather.  If it's not naturally hot, the heater is on full power... You need cold packs in winter for the buses. >___>

Between cities? It's really far you know...  A lot of people use bicycles a lot of the time.  They aren't all that convenient in the city cores (some areas don't allow them and parking can be difficult... furthermore you're supposed to stay on the road but roads are tiny so you really are switching back and forth from sidewalk to road and avoiding pedestrians)... but outside of the core they are effective within a city. Going city to city though... it's far. I mean, taking a slow pace... sure... setouchi is popular. I'm not sure of the amenities out in the countryside, but you'd have to be able to pace yourself. Also, as they say... since crime is rare, the 3 jobs of the police are to give directions, watch the foreigners, and make sure no one is stealing bicycles. So if you're foreign riding a bicycle, you're like, the primary focus. =P

JR pass mostly covers the national train network between cities. In particular, you are paying for the high speed shinkansen, which you can use as much as you want, minus a couple exceptions. JR also covers some of the trains in several of the major cities. However, the network within cities is a lot weaker. Additionally, the rate you'd pay within a city is much lower than the day by day cost of the JR pass. In practice, this means if you want to buy a JR pass, it should start as close to the time of your first shinkansen as possible, and end as close to the time you exit your last shinkansen as possible. This means that you will generally pay as you go (using an IC card) in your first or last city, or both. It also means you will probably need to pay some costs to subway companies in each city, even when your JR pass is active.

A week? You don't need much. Courtesy words. It's not like most people speak much English... but I wouldn't think you'd go too far off the tourist track within a week, which should at least have SOMEONE there who can help you in English if needed.  So in that case, you could mostly do fine with just gestures... and if necessary, you would likely be able to find someone who can speak it.  That said, you are a year off from going... maybe even almost two years off. Again, not sure if you're really getting much return on investment for time spent learning if you'll only be there a week... but you have time to invest. Even just one word a week puts you at a strong advantage going over there. Recommended words: Numbers 1 to 10 at least, 100, 1000, 10000 helpful for money. Direction words. Simple locations- bathroom, station, park Courtesy words: sumimasen, arigatou, douzo, etc.  The more you know... the more you can take advantage of... the better you can enjoy things a bit more off the beaten path, and maybe even meet some people who don't speak English well. A lot of things would be quite hard without at least being able to read some, and not being able to speak Japanese will almost always cost you some time and money in country (failure to take advantage of discounts, time lost being lost, etc). Knowing more will improve your time. But... you can do fine without it, and it's probably not an efficient use of time to learn much just for the 1 week of travel.

Going just to Tokyo, and only for a week... it's going to significantly depend on where you're coming from... and to a lesser degree on your interests and how budget friendly you plan to make it.  But a week... you could easily do for 700 USD + plane ticket... but I'd still at least have access to 1000 USD. I doubt you'd actually even get close to 700 on just day to day stuff... but that gives a lot of leeway should you want to haul a bunch of stuff home.  Over two weeks your leeway need decreases and some things with higher up front costs starts to give a better per day average... and it'd probably be more like 1200 USD (access to 1600) + plane ticket. But once you start going that long people generally want to go visit other cities... which increases costs significantly. I personally have no issue keeping entertained for 3+ weeks in just Tokyo though.  Anyway, this is just a general estimate knowing nothing about you... you can go cheaper if your tastes are inexpensive- nature, shrines etc, or significantly more, as the sky is really the limit on prices in Tokyo. This presumes a hostel or something like that....if you go with at least one other person, the per person costs should decrease and/or you can get much better lodging for the price.

Generally... you just count it as cents.  So if something is 500 yen... it's 500 cents... or 5 dollars. So that's the benchmark people use as a quick estimate... it's super easy. However, it does fluctuate between about 80 and 120 yen to the dollar though. Right now, the dollar is strong versus the yen, so it's been around 110 yen to the dollar. So you basically just run the same calculation, and then give yourself a 10% discount for having the right currency at the right time.  So a 1000 yen thing is 1000 cents... or 10 dollars... but you get a 10% discount now so you count it as 9 dollars.

Budget oriented. Generally bunks in a room, and shared areas.  However many of the hostels in Japan are capsule style in a room, or sometimes even private rooms now. So, they aren't fancy. You don't always have privacy. But since stuff is shared, you sometimes actually have more amenities than a hotel- usually a full kitchen to work with, for example. While you don't have to talk to anyone... they're much more social. A hotel you'd mostly keep to yourself... at a hostel, you'd maybe come back after a long day, buy a couple beers at a convenience store, and go back and chat with other people about their travels.

Housing that meets the standards of most middle-class westerners is expensive, but the vast majority of Japanese people, especially the younger generation and those who are still single or don't have kids, live in much, much smaller homes/apartments, and it's very common for salaried jobs to also have the benefit of partially subsidized housing, ie your employer pays for part of your housing, or has some sort of arrangement with a management company to give slightly cheaper rent. Crime rates are very low, so lower income areas are nowhere near as scary, most are totally fine, and there are a lot of factors that are actually super affordable compared to places like America. Owning a car is very expensive, for example, but you don't really need to in most cases, because public transit is both efficient and reasonably affordable. Reasonably healthy food is also very affordable as well. If you're cooking for yourself, it's probably about the same, but there's much more available that's convenient and relatively healthy compared to any sort of convenience foods you find in western countries.   Another big one is health care. While some things, like over the counter medicine, are more expensive, most parts of their healthcare system are vastly more affordable, and the Japanese spend far less yearly out of pocket for medical expenses than America does. This is a pretty well established problem in America, so they're a relatively exaggerated comparison, but one that's probably the most relevant for most of the people thinking about this sort of thing. The Japanese also go to the doctor much more frequently on average, which combined with the relatively affordable healthy food, makes it a very healthy country overall, which helps with the reduced medical costs in general.   I've seen a couple videos that break all this down, and it seems to work out that, for the average single person, the cost to maintain a reasonable, middle class standard of living for Japan is actually much lower than many people think it is, even living in the middle of Tokyo, and often works out to a fair bit less than most places in America. The lifestyle is just different. If you feel like you need to have a big suburban home with a sizable lawn, 1-3 cars, and two dogs, then yea, Japan is gonna be pretty expensive.

I think the main problem besides cost is... ticket sales are already going on sale.  Like, literally after the new year.  I'm not sure things are popular enough to sell out, but you're losing priority the longer you wait to buy... and you just don't have the mobility to be able to buy with something fuzzy like 70-140 people.  I don't know what will be left by the time you could get something organized.  Also, even the pool is over a 3 week or so period over a relatively large swath of Japan even just to see only the Ireland matches.  Since you can't just stay in one area or so, cost will be a bit higher. And 3 weeks + travel time would be like a month long trip... so, it'd probably not hit all the pool matches.  More than likely, you'd want to get in touch with a travel agent... maybe the official one they're using... as they'd be able to secure tickets without having to go through the Japanese lottery systems.  I doubt you'd be able to pull it off for under 1500 euro per person for a 10 days in country (~12ish total) without some sort of government subsidy or deal. Which, if you really are a rugby school, may be possible... you'd have to ask... may get you better seats too or some bonus stuff. Also, that's a low-ball that depends on getting a decent plane price. If asking people to put down 1500 Euro already seems ridiculous, well, then it's probably not going to happen and you should start planning just for yourself. If 1500 Euro seems possible, remember that you'd have to work hard to get it that low and it will probably be higher.

Bought breakfast, cleaned up and changed in the station washroom, then started looking around. The seat was more comfortable than some budget hotel beds I've slept in. Was it as good as a hotel and  then a skinkansen? No, but it was a tiny fraction of the cost. It's a completely different experience from the KL-Singapore bus trip, which is just terrible. (take the overnight train instead...it's cheap, and you get a sleeper car, often to yourself.
One word: restrooms.
I have no problems sleeping on the overnight buses. I fall asleep easier in the car and on trains/etc than I do in an actual bed.

Doable. If you're going to Hiroshima, also visit Miyajima. Â If Miyajima doesn't interest you, go to Okunoshima where rabbits run around free on the island then go to Hiroshima after. Â And Kyoto is not that far from Osaka. Takes about 28 minutes on Limited Express, 29 minutes on Special Â Rapid Service trains, 40 minutes on Rapid Service trains; all JR. Â  Check out Japan-guide, Japan  Visitor or JNTO for ideas on where to go and how to get there. No matter what, you'll enjoy your visit there. I f you like castles, Himeji is not that far from Osaka; 44 minutes by Shinkansen via Shin-Osaka station or ~65 minutes by JR Special Rapid Service. Of course, there's Osaka Castle as well.  Â If you like Hayao Miyazaki movies, try to get a ticket in advance for Ghibli Museum in Mitaka (Tokyo).  Check out Koyasan and Kumano Naichi Taisha/Naichi Waterfall in Wakayama Prefecture. Both are beautiful, but are long day trips from Osaka, Â especially for Naichi Waterfall.

I have visited Japan twice now, once last summer 2016 and just now Dec. 2017.  Yes, there are definitely things that are expensive especially in Tokyo but boy, you also have lots of cheap options.  This video is really good but I just want to clarify some things and/or add info.  The Tokyo subway is vast and is operated by multiple different lines (private and government).  One is a private company which is Japan Rail who also operate the Shinkansen.  You can only get the Japan Rail pass outside of Japan as a tourist and is definitely worth it.  Like the video says, it only takes one long ride on the Shinkansen to make the 1 week pass worth it and on top of that you can ride the Japan Rail trains in the city for free.  BUT, here is the clarification, JR is not the metro/subway, it is only a portion of it.  There is a massive network of trains.  If you ONLY got the JR pass, you cannot ride the rest of the subway system in Tokyo.  You can only ride on the trains operated by JR.  Now the video is wrong in that it says you have to stand around buying tickets if you don't get the JR pass.  That's also not true.  What you should do is to buy a PASMO or SUICA card.  These are literally train debit cards and they work across all these different train companies.  They come preloaded with amounts and you can just tap your way through all the trains and it will deduct an amount each time.  No need to go buy a ticket each time and figure out how much it costs.  When the balance runs low (and you'll see your balance every time you tap),  you can just re-charge them in the ticket machines.  I got mine from Haneda airport and when I left I just returned it at the airport and I got a 500 Yen deposit refund for the card.  Concerning the food, I would definitely pick Yoshinoya over the other ones.  I find its quality just a bit better and the prices just as good.  But I had a lunch at Nakajima in Shinjuku and it is a 1 Michelin Star restaurant.  Guess how much the lunch is:  800 Yen!  So how's that for a budget lunch at a 1 Michelin star restaurant.  It opens at 11:30am so lineup early.  I waited just short of an hour but if you get there like 11:30am your wait should be shorter.  There is also a 1 Michelin star ramen place in Tokyo (near Sengoku) and cheapest ramen is 1000 Yen, its name is Tsuta.  And there are many other top notch ramen shops whose prices are cheaper too.  I also find 7 Eleven, Lawson, Family Mart to be full of good stuff to buy but you can try their local grocery stores and they have even MORE items with the same prices.  And the food shops in the train stations are amazing and tons of selection with excellent prices.  I also agree with the video's recommendation of business hotel.  I got one last year and it slept 3 of us plenty well with a kitchen/dining table too and it was just a bit higher than the capsule hotel prices.  Happy travels in Japan!

In addition to the country-wide JR pass, there are a number of JR Rail passes available. The JR East Rail pass is particularly attractive because it allows for 5 non-continuous days of use within a 14 day period, at a cost of 20,000 yen, (less than US$200). You have more freedom to stay more than one night with this pass.  With the nation-wide JR pass, in order to maximize the value, you need to travel very frequently to maximize the value. The JR East Pass covers the widest area of Japan, and includes Tokyo. You can purchase more than one regional pass, and wait until you start your travel to activate it. Details here: https://www.japan-rail-pass.com/pass-regional.

I have traveled several times. I live in Arizona and the price of a ticket from Phoenix is about $1000 dollars during the summer (which happens to be the most popular time to go) so I would drive to LAX to get a cheap ticket for roughly $560. A single bed hostel for $40-$60 a night over two weeks. We usually party a lot and go to clubs or bars there which had us sp ending about $600 a week. I would suggest if you're looking to travel all over Japan transportastion will cost you minimum $100 a week if you use the subway system. All in all I would recommend you save about $2500 minimum ($3000 to be safe) to be safe if you want to stay for two weeks. If you want to have a really good time I would suggest getting bottle service at a club. If you go with a few people the total bill will run about $800 with tip and gratuity. The most I've personally spent during a two week period in Japan was about $5500 and I went to a bar/club every other day. Figure out what you want to do when you're there and what the end goal is. If you wanna get super drunk and have some fun, be prepared to spend a lot of cash. If you want to travel around the area and sight see, no more than $3000 should be required. Hope this helped everyone break it down.

A lot of hostels have capsule style beds.  So basically you have walls, and preferably, side entry. They are fairly large... you can sit up in them. And I keep my backpack and such in the capsule with me.  If anything, the amount of bedding they give you take a bunch of space and is a little annoying. But I'm 6 feet and can sleep in them normally... so worst case scenario you may have to sleep diagonally if you want to sleep totally stretched out. But I don't think you should run into trouble with these. The capsules designed for Japanese businessmen? Well, those, I don't know. So I'd recommend going to a place that's actually advertising/listed online on English language sites... there would likely be both pictures and reviews as well.

People tend to have time OR money, but rarely a lot of both. If you have a salary job with hardly any vacation time, you go and splurge to get the best out of your 10 days or whatever.  If you're a student you can probably get away for 4+ weeks at a time, if only you had the money. These are the sorts of people that care about budget.  Wasting money on one trip delays my next trip. I don't suggest convini anyway except as... well... what they are, convenience! Grocery store is way better for cheap food. But 500-1200 yen fast food and ramen shops are plentiful and delicious. I still eat some fancy stuff, but I'm perfectly satisfied with a 1200 yen sashimi bowl lunch and 600 yen katsu bowl dinner.  Maybe average 2200 yen per day on food with occasional splurges. If I go 30 days at a time, 2200 yen versus a 6000 yen food budget is about 1000 USD.

You will find most good food is fairly cheap in Japan, unless you are going for high end stuff obviously. Also you are really missing out if you donâ€™t visit 7/11 or other konbini chain on your trip the range and quality of food is completely different to the rest of the world. Trust me konbini onigiri will be your lord and saviour.

You go to a website like kayak. You type in your nearest major airport, and then you make your destination Tokyo, any airport. That would search for Haneda and Narita airports. Pick a few days, and search. See what the smallest number of connections is. If you live near Dallas or Houston, there should be direct flights to Tokyo... I don't know about other airports.  You'll want to check the prices. Sometimes these go on sale... but you're probably stuck taking some sort of out of the way route to keep the price down. You'll have to make a judgement call on how much of a detour is worth the price savings. And again, non-stop deals can happen... check the flight prices often and making sign up for price alert e-mails.  Haneda airport is in Tokyo, and about a 30-60 minute train ride to where you'd probably actually be staying.  Narita airport is in the neighboring prefecture and takes about 60-120 minutes by train to get to where you'd probably actually be staying. Most international flights go through Narita.

Well, I don't think he's an expert at that. Nor am I.  And it depends a LOT on the ages of those kids.  I'd generally suggest airbnb so you can get something a little bigger than a hotel, for less than a hotel  Understand that there are some children's fares for the trains, and some very young are free with adult tickets.  And strollers/prams out in the major tourist areas... are rare.  And traditional places aren't necessarily going to have access at all. It's a safe country, but there's a lot of walking involved so it's not that convenient with really young kids.  If they're a bit older so that they can more or less walk around on their own, and at least have an interest in Pokemon or something if nothing else, then you can start planning a bit differently.  Nevertheless, you should be able to budget for around 150-220 USD per day depending on exact family size, ages, and interests + flight cost + long-distance travel... plus any big one time expenses such as Disney.

Re drinking in public in the UK. I've heard you mention it a few times but drinking in public is not illegal or banned in the UK. Local councils have the power place a 'no drinking' order on an area, so whether you can drink in public is entirely location dependent, e.g. some parts of London you can drink in public other parts you can't.

There are few government owned public restrooms.  Mostly parks, and a few here and there.  Most are attached to businesses and business districts, so quality will vary. Train station restrooms are usually the most convenient since you usually have to start and end your trips there anyway. They're usually really spartan. Japanese have a thing for cleanliness so they are still usually pretty okay... no helping the men's restroom around late rush hour though (ie, drunk from afterwork drinking party man's rush hour).  Lost cause.  Some stations will only have squat toilets. But yeah, go to a 5th floor department store's bathroom and it will be immaculate. But that's the problem... it's like 4 escalators up and down to get to the first toilet since they want to discourage the less determined. These places also close relatively early.

Well, I wouldn't deny that companies merge... it happens all the time, but your statement did cause me to dig more into it.  Basically all the big name beers have their roots in the 1870s and 1880s. In the spirit of Japanese co-operation and price fixing, most of these formed more or less a monopoly in 1906.  The companies were split again in 1949. So, 20-30 years separate, 40 years together, and now 60-70ish years for their taste to have diverged.

yeah you're right although it wasn't a monopoly - Kirin, Suntory etc. were also a major producers. "In 1933, DaiNippon Beer absorbed Nippon Beer Kosen and unsuccessfully attempted to merge with Kirin Brewery, which agreed to co-establish a joint beer sales company with DaiNippon Beer. Sakura Brewery also co-established a sales company with the joint sales company. The establishment of these sales companies enabled beer companies to voluntarily coordinate production and sales, bringing stability to the beer market."

I recommend pre-booking everything.  But with airbnb and such available now it's not as vital. The main reason I recommend it is simply because it's something you can get done from home.  Anything you can research and get done from home saves you time in country. And unlike say, a backpack tour of Europe where you can see drastic changes country to country and one place may be a lot less your style than you had thought,  the differences from one place to another in Japan will be more subtle.  You should be able to have a good idea of how long you want to stay in each place before arriving. Also, while I have been able to find last minute accommodation in Japan- booking like 8 days in a row... that sort of thing... that does in fact  often dry up and you get stuck wasting time moving your crap around/checking in to extra places you can only stay 1-4 days or whatever.  Also, pretty much as soon as you move out of Tokyo, Kyoto and Osaka, your hostels choices go way down and you have to rely on airbnb if you wait too long- which is usually fine of course. For example, I looked up Fukuoka- a huge city with not enough hostels. Right now, there are 3 available for late October- one has no rating because it hasn't been in business recently... one is really far out from the city center, and one is actually passable but only has a few male dorm beds left. So, basically, ALREADY nothing, so you'd have to airbnb there.  The other major reason I recommend pre-booking is that your transportation costs depend a lot on where you will be going. You can't really make an intelligent transportation purchase without at least a skeleton itinerary.  And I say this as someone who likes a lot of flexibility. I plan the skeleton well, but leave the day to day stuff fairly open.  Of course, Japan is pretty easy and most things are safe. So if flexibility is your thing, then go for it. But I'd still suggest planning out a skeleton itinerary even if you don't book anything.

If you're getting the rail pass, pay the extra for the business class "green car"  - that's where the real value comes into play.   Not for the extra comfort (that too, but...) You're much more likely to get a seat ticket at any given time for any ride of the day in business, but while in regular class these can be booked up many weeks in advance and you cannot reserve a seat until you're in Japan.  You see, the pass only gives you the right to ride stand-by on the train.   The seat ticket is free with the pass, but these must be reserved first.  You will want a seat ticket to get an assigned seat, especially if you're travelling with another person so you can sit together.    Also, the business class section is much quieter since only corporate executives and celebrities are reimbursed to ride in those sections.  Else, you might end up being in a car with a bunch of high school girls that will drive you insane.  Also keep in mind the pass might be pretty worthless for many subway systems.  Tokyo metro, for example, is not valid with the pass and is a far more efficienct way of getting around Tokyo than with JR.

The only time I ever couldn't get the exact train I wanted was a sakura shinkansen  from Osaka to Fukuoka... during Golden Week. It's not really much of an issue. And... this may be BS and if so, I apologize, but one time I had a schedule change and despite the hikari I wanted showing up as "X", or, sold out... they gave me a ticket anyway. It specifically said "JR pass ticket" or something like that. So... apparently there are a few in reserve for JR pass users, at least on hikari trains, at least if you show up before the last minute to get your ticket.  The basic area is sufficiently spacious, especially compared to planes, and the upcharge is fairly significant. (10000 7 day,  16000 14 day, 22000 21 day). It's in play, but I don't know if I'll ever get it. I rather spend the 16000-22000 yen somewhere else.  That said... if you happen to take a Platt Kodama train, the upcharge is only 1500 extra yen from Tokyo to Shin-Osaka. Of course, taking Platt Kodama in the first place probably means you're on a budget, but if the point is more to enjoy the ride than get there quickly, a green car ride on a platt kodama may be a nice trip.

I went to Tokyo for one week in February 2016. A flight in the off season from LA to Tokyo cost me about $800. I found an Air BnB in a residential neighborhood for around $55/night, and I got the Japan Rail Pass for about, I believe, $210. Before I left, I went to a local bank, and did a currency exchange for $200 into Yen (About 20,000 JPY). So, combined airfare, accommodations, and local travel came to about $1400. I paid for all of my meals using the yen I got before I left, with the exception of a 6 course Wagyu beef dinner I splurged on and paid for with my debit card (about $150).  $3200 is definitely enough to take a trip, but there are a couple things you can do to save money. If you're sticking to Tokyo, you would probably be better off not getting the rail pass, and just paying for local train trips piecemeal. I took a day trip to Kyoto via bullet train if for no other reason than to justify the money I spent on the pass. Additionally, I was relatively frugal with what I did. I avoided many restaurants, especially if they did not have an english menu, as I don't have a firm grasp on the language. my breakfasts were simple, a pastry from a nearby bakery, or fruit from a market. Lunch was usually Ramen, and dinner often inexpensive (sushi or, one night, a kebab bowl). I didn't go out drinking, stayed away from a lot of the expensive tourist offerings or guided tours, and opted mostly for exploring the city on my own, getting lost, and checking out free or low-price attractions. (Tokyo Government building observation deck, Ramen Museum, Imperial Palace exterior grounds, wandering around Golden-gai)  Sorry for the wall of text. Hope this helps!

Back when I was stationed in Japan (I left in 2007), I would frequently stay over night in the net cafes.  (something like this: https://taylordavidson.com/2009/sleeping-at-an-internet-cafe-in-tokyo-a-recommended-experience)  They'd usually cost about $12 or so a night. They were quiet. If you know the right ones, they will have private showers for 150 yen. You also have access to the internet, TV, manga, etc. so you have plenty of entertainment. They are very quiet. Oh, free open fountain drinks as well. I mainly did it when I got tired of going back to the base or wanted to travel around on a budget.  During my time there, I met quite a few men who lived in this way. They didn't earn enough to really have an apartment and worked too much to really justify the expense anyways. So, they would sleep and shower in a net cafe near their office and rent lockers by the week to store their stuff.

Great video! Yeah, a lot of people make out Japan to be a super expensive place but, it is actually quite affordable. Since Korea is really close to Japan I've visited on multiple occasions for shopping and touring. From those experiences I guarantee you can save A LOT of money if you plan properly.  A lot of the parts people make mistakes in when planning is transportation. You can literally spend days worth of hotel fees on transportation if your not smart about it. So here are some rules to keep in mind if your traveling on a budget.  RULE #1 Never use a taxi! You might feel a little lazy or bewildered on how to get to your destination. But, in most major cities of Japan public and private transportation is very well developed. And taxis are EXPENSIVE. A twenty minute drive will land you over 2000 yen.  If you happen to lose your way to a destination just ask for directions. :) Japanese are very kind in that aspect. Even if you can't speak a word of Japanese, showing them a destination in google map is often enough and they will help you out as much as possible. Seriously in several occassions strangers walked me all the way to the destination!  RULE #2 Always check where you are visiting.  I advise people who visit Japan to check where they want to visit before hand(or at least the major stops) and check if their subway pass or any sort of travel pass they've got covers the locations. I've seen a lot of people having to get new tickets or passes because the train lines they wished to take were not covered by there travel pass.   For instance Osaka has like three different subway/train lines all with seperate payment because they fall under different companies. So the pass you have might only cover one of those lines and not the others.  RULE #3 Check your travel objective. This might be a little overlaping with Rule #2 but, hear me out. Depending on your travel objective the type of travel pass or transportation ticket you'd want to get will vary.  Drastically.   If you look up the different travel passes, you can easily find that there are passes designed for shoppers, sight seekers, long term or short term travel. They also come with different perks for specific people, like discounts to museum or castle entrance fees and so on.  RULE #4 Step away from that hotel. Not being able to stay at a hotel might seem like a bummer. But if your going to half ass and stay at an average hotel it is much better to go for guest houses or Air Bnb deals. Especailly if your traveling with friends of 3~4 Air bnb can be a god send. Some guest houses will also have interesting tourist guides to the local area. The kind of experiences you'd normally not know if you went to a fancy hotel.  Woah this has gotten out of control...  Well you can sense my excitement with traveling to Japan.   I've said rules and what not, but remember its just a trip.  You don't have to follow your plans by the book.  Just have a blast and enjoy your stay in Japan like I've did. :)

To be frank, it depends a lot on how many people are going and what they wanted to do. His guide provided a lot of options, but the best course depends on your exact situation.  That said, as a general estimate, I suggest: 100 USD/day + flight + long-distance transportation + 200 USD buffer Of the 100 USD/day, about 50-60/day will be on "required" stuff- lodging, (basic)food, (basic) transportation.  And 40-50 USD/day is for fun- entry fees, event tickets, buying stuff, fancier food or drink, day trip transportation, etc.  For a 4 day trip, your long-distance transportation is probably 0. For a 7 day trip, you'd want to decide if it's worth going to another region or just sticking to Tokyo OR Osaka/Kyoto.  You probably won't need to use much if any of the buffer- that's why it's a buffer. However, on a short trip you're at risk of not "averaging out"... on a two week trip there will almost certainly be some cheap days that help balance out your splurge days. If you just go four days they may all be splurge days and so the recommendation may be low. So make sure you have some extra available as buffer.   For a 7 day, 6 night  trip, I would just go to Tokyo. If you never plan to go to Japan ever again then it'd be hard to not recommend going to Tokyo + Kyoto, but for me going, I'd just do one or the other.  Lodging would be about 27*6  Basic food 20*7 (one solid inexpensive meal (800-1200), one fast food meal (400-700), snack (100-300) + vending machine x2-3 (200-300))  Wifi: 40- wifi cost is front-loaded with rentals- this is a high estimate for this length of stay  Transportation: 20 (to/from airport) + 30 (two 72 hour passes) + 10 (assorted random costs)  My recommended was 100 USD/day + 200 USD buffer... which means 900 USD + flight for this trip. My lodging + basic food + wifi + transportation = 402 USD. That leaves about 300 USD- or about 30 USD/day for fun with 90 USD to buy some stuff, before breaking into your buffer.

While a taxi is hardly ever a good option, it's not never a good option, particularly if there are at least 3 and ideally 4 of you. They're ridiculously expensive, but if your route is relatively short but requires a train company transfer (metro to JR, for example), the taxi can come out ahead with a party of 4 and close enough to be worth saving the trouble with 3. But the reality is we're so used to not even considering taxis in Tokyo that I'm always halfway to the destination before I realize that it was actually a taxi-ideal route and then it's too late to be worth it.

+redfish337 I guess you are right on that. But, most of the time people would already be in possesion of travel passes that cover subways or buses. "a lot of people make out Japan to be a super expensive place but, it is actually quite affordable"  This is because compared to many nearby countries it is vastly more expensive. Maybe 5x as as expensive as Vietnam, Thailand, Malaysia, or Indonesia, 2-3x  the price of Taiwan, or Singapore, and even a bit more expensive than Hong Kong!  For someone from SK maybe you don't realise it because SK and JP are similarly priced.  And yes, taxi are always a scam in all counties. Use Uber or Grab for a fraction of the cost, easier to use and faster, plus they have accountability.

People aren't comparing Japan with Thailand and Malaysia. Japan... probably from the bubble years, had a reputation as being the most expensive country, period.  That's their rep, and it's been their rep for decades.  People don't expect Japan to be cheap. They expect it to be expensive- even more expensive than Western countries, even beating out the Nordic countries. I mean, if you're from the West and they're telling you Japan is expensive, you're expecting it to be more expensive than where you're from.  And right now... ehh... not really.

I just returned from a 3 week visit to Japan.  We found it very affordable, besides the cost of getting there and back from near the East coast of the United States.  We stayed in Airbnb's for 3 weeks (3 of us) for $1100 total US.  Our meals and transportation between cities, including entrance to attractions and souvenirs was about another $900-1000 US.  This was for 3 adults.  We didn't eat expensively, except one or twice.  This was an average of around $100 US per person per day however, excepting airfare to/from Japan.  We thought Japan was a very affordable destination.  And we visited Tokyo, Osaka, Kyoto, Nara, Kobe, Kanazawa and Nagoya (and we went to Disney Seas in Tokyo too).  We did purchase the Japan Rail Pass for 2 weeks, but I'm not sure it was actually worth the cost.  It might have been cheaper to a shorter term area pass quite honestly.

Ryoko007 the best way to get a cheap flight is to book more than 6 months in advance. I also made the experience during my Japan trips that's it's better to book a flight from a travel agency since their prices are never worse than those you can find online. Last time Everyone even got a free 2 big luggage place for free. But the main reason was that we weren't able to checkin for our flight because of strange technical issues and I called our agent and she helped us out immediately. From the other side of the world! Otherwise we would have had to spend a ridiculous amount of money to get a taxi to narita airport because it was already very late, buses were all gone, trains stopped and out flight was very early. You can book hotels and other things over the Internet but for your flight, which is the most crucial part - get an agent.

Being a student myself, two years ago in Japan, one way to safe money was indeed a late discount in supermarkets. In some supermarket at that time (Kasumi or Seiyu) after 9pm, there were discounts for bento (ready to eat food), sometimes I had to pay half price

It's also worth noting that A LOT of the hostels in the inner cities don't just have 8-12 bed dorms. Many of the places I stayed had 2-4 person rooms as well, making it a lot easier to travel in a pair/small group and still have complete privacy from others.

These are great tips. I've done all of them and while some (*cough* night bus *cough*) are far from comfortable they all serve their purpose and help keep things cheap letting you explore more of Japan. Just a word of caution though. If you speak little to no Japanese most of these options will be a bit more difficult as most of the time the fluent English speaking customer service is found in medium to high-end touristy places. A lot of people in Japan speak a little English at least though and they are the most accommodating people in the world so the majority will be more than happy to play some charades and wait for you to type out every sentence on a translator. A trip like this with limited Japanese is totally doable just don't go into any of these places expecting people to speak English even in Tokyo.(Also pro tip if you don't have a translator handy try writing what you want in simple English. Japanese people study reading and writing far more than speaking so it could save your bacon in a pinch but I would still come prepared.)    Another thing to keep in mind is luggage. You will have at most a very thin locker for storage so I wouldn't bring a big suitcase. I always had my pack in with me when I was in a capsule hotel or a hostel and had a smaller bag with my money, passport, camera etc. that I would lock up with a padlock I carried with me. Japan is VERY safe but you still need to take precautions, especially where you'll mostly be encountering other travellers. Sidenote for the ladies. Finding a capsule hotel will be a lot harder for you. They were originally designed for businessmen and they are divided by sex so there are far more for men than there are for women. There are a few in Tokyo that are divided by floor but they are few and far between so book early if you want to go that route (and you should I really recommend it!). Also, both men and women should prepare themselves for the bath options at capsule hotels and some hostels. It's usually done onsen style so if you aren't comfortable being naked in front of a room full of strangers you may want to go for the business or love hotel. Furthermore, if you have any tattoos you will need to make sure you're allowed to stay there as well since some places that use onsen style bathing have the same restrictions as most other onsens and gyms and won't let you in with tatts.   Also, a couple tips for the night bus, while the website is in English the customer service and drivers probably will NOT be English speaking. My friends and I were supposed to catch a night bus in Shinjuku once and there were about 50+ night buses lined up 20 minutes before we were scheduled to leave, none of them ours so I spent a pretty frantic time talking to the woman on the service line in my broken Japanese that was still the best in the group. We finally found it but it probably took about a year off my life in extra stress. If you do decide to do the night-bus you will be in desperate need of a shower and if you're not planning to check in to a hotel for awhile there's kind of a weird trick. Most internet cafes have showers you can rent for set periods of time. I haven't tried this method myself as I was always checking in somewhere when I got to my destination so I can't testify personally but look into it if you're desperate. Also on the night bus, I would definitely recommend springing for the slightly more expensive seat. It makes a world of difference, you have much more leg room and you're not surrounded so closely on both sides. For me, it meant waking up after a restful night's sleep for the first time in about a dozen night bus trips and I never went back!   Most of all though enjoy Japan. It's truly an amazing experience! I'd recommend you use all the money you save to treat yourself to some sort of fun experience that is uniquely Japanese and get the most out of your trip rather than spend the whole time counting yen and stressing the conversion. Be flexible, be patient, and be open to new experiences. Don't panic if things don't go exactly according to plan and take the chance to explore if you miss your stop or get lost somewhere. Trust me on this. ;)

July and August have a lot more festivals and events, particularly at night. The weather is brutally hot and humid. September's weather starts improving, but doesn't really reach a turning point until the 20th-25th or so. Despite still being quite hot, there are fewer activities in September so it's a lot of extra suffering for nothing. =P October is probably the 3rd best month in terms of weather. If you're there towards the end you may even be able to catch some of the change to autumn leaves, though it may take a day trip out to altitude. This whole period is technically typhoon season, though typhoons to Tokyo area don't tend to be much more than a bad 1 day rainstorm (Fukuoka and western areas get hit worse and more often). They can still happen in October, but they start to be less common. I strongly recommend late September or October if you have a choice. Summer is love/hate... if you end up loving Japan and decide you want to go to Obon in Kyoto, or Tokushima Awaodori, or Aomori Nebuta or some of the mostly July fireworks festivals... or climb Mt. Fuji if you're crazy, or some other stuff... there's stuff that is great that you can only do in summer that you may decide is worth the weather. And other stuff that is just culturally summer. But, the weather sucks. Really sucks. Save it for when you're a bit more of a pro so you don't have to deal with culture shock/confusion + heat/humidity at the same time, or your schedule obligates you to go then. There's still plenty to see in October! And for all the stuff you can see any time of year, that's a far more enjoyable time! ALSO, although variable, flights tend to be more expensive in summer than you can get most other times of year.

About 900-1200 USD / month for smallish apartment.... 600-900 USD/month for sharehouse (own room + common areas), 350-500 USD/month for dormitory.  But the sky is the limit of course... price is heavily dependent on station and distance to station. Cheaper options may also be available with some luck and searching... but unless you're really on a shoestring budget you should look for value rather than the rock bottom price.

I was hoping around 1200-1600 for something with personal appliances (bath, toilet, bed, cooking, ect.) so this is good news. I can probably get something pretty decent for that price. Thanks for the info.

Chilly/cold... can possibly snow a little, but usually doesn't. Christmas Eve is a dating/spend time as couple Holiday. Christmas is a minor family holiday... everything should still be open, it's really minor. Things will nevertheless be decorated for Christmas, and there will be Christmas lights in many places. People go and visit the various Christmas light "illuminations" around the city through December.  New Years is the big holiday. Golden Week in May is a "do something" holiday so things get busier and businesses make a lot of money... New Years is the "visit relatives"  holiday. A lot of stuff closes. A lot of things may already be closed by the 29th or even earlier.  Travel can get quite busy around then as well. The bulk of the Holiday is during and then after New Years though, so you'll mostly miss it. HOWEVER, especially for perhaps 28th-29th, make sure stuff you want to do will be open!   The National Museum (and others)  is closed from the 26th, for example! They take an early vacation so that they can be open for the days after New Year but before most people go back to work.  And Mom and pop shops may decide to take a few extra days off! Do anything you REALLY want to do beforehand... even if stuff is open, they'll be winding down! (eg, a mom and pop shop that runs out of so and so probably isn't replacing it just ahead of a week-long holiday).

stayed in Tokyo a couple weeks, 20$ a night, cheaper if you really look, transportation, you can get some pass that will cover all transportation for a certain duration and it's really cheap, cheaper than paying for busses and trains individually. especially if your traveling far distances such as to other cities or prefectures, it's for tourists only and can't be continuously bought though. food will be about 10$ a meal unless your going to expensive places, you can get down to a few dollars a meal if your fine with food that's not the best *cough*711*cough*. the real kicker is the plane ticket and shopping, book early and off season for a cheap flight, hold in the reigns for shopping. Honestly it was cheaper living in Japan for the few weeks I was there than it is here in Canada so...

Japan was the first non-Western power to basically become a "Western power".  They were the first to get the Olympics for example. Japan has been a place with the modernity comfortable to those from the West, with the allure of being Eastern.  As an aside, China is and has been Communist. Especially during the Cold War, that put them at an extreme disadvantage in terms of exporting their culture. South Korea has been on friendly terms with the West for a long time, but they were dealing with the Korean War and aftermath as Japan was finishing rebuilding and turning into an economic powerhouse.    So you can look at modern pop culture and say that say, K-pop or Chinese movies, are beating Japan internationally- but Japan has had say, the modern concept of the ninja, or samurai or Godzilla ingrained in the Western imagination for decades. And in modern times it's not just anime- Nintendo revived the video game industry, and that means all their big name franchises are some of the biggest names in video games. Power rangers, to hello kitty, to harajuku styles... they've just got SOOO many angles at this point.

My numbers: Housing: $28.80/day Transport $6.10/day Food:  $16.40/day... but $20/day is more reasonable (I was occasionally treated) Wi-fi:  $3.50/day - you can definitely get cheaper... I just typically need a high end one  Those are your "needs" and I will round up to $29, 7, 20 and 4, for convenience, which is $60/day... or about $1800 for the month.  That leaves a good  $700-1200 to play and buy crap. Which should be more than sufficient for the average tourist. Want to buy a LOT of crap? Then you'll need more money. But that'd be because of expensive tastes, not because going to Japan itself is expensive.

I went with just a backpack, and a thousand dollars. I used couchsurfing.com to find locals that had free room and board, met some AMAZING people. I even met the geisha from one of your videos at Spa World after the Biking the shiminami kaido bike trail. I went to the grocery stores after 7pm, everything was 50% off if not higher, and I got the JR rail pass before I left. I ended up taking 1000 dollars worth of bullet trains for half the price. And I got to see the coolest places thanks to you. Sendai was great. I followed the cherry blossoms from onnomochi to Hiroshima through Kyoto, up to Tokyo and did a side trip up north. Thanks for everything.

Skateboards aren't legal for street use though, believe it or not. Avoid cops, because they will catch you and give you a face full about how you're not allowed to use a skateboard on sidewalks, streets, roads, etc. How do I know? I live here. If you want speed and budget, road bike is by far the best way to go. Or, just buy a used bike. That will set you back around 8,000 to 12,000 yen, depending. It won't be a fancy 21 speed, but you can definitely get around with it.

I took two night buses (Willer Express)when I was in Japan. One from Tokyo to Kyoto. The other one was from Osaka to Tokyo. It's super cheap. Just be prepared, because it can be a little weird to a foreigner to be sleeping next to Japanese people you don't know. And they pull the curtains down on the overnight buses, so you don't really see the scenery outside the window. However, I met my Japanese friend from Osaka  (on the Osaka to Tokyo bus) by choosing this option. So it was definitely worth it!
In April I spent 18 days in Tokyo and stayed in Shinjuku at an Airbnb. It ended up costing me $35 a night for it, definitely would try an Airbnb again.

When I went to Japan, I didn't use the JR railpass and I didn't sleep in a bus. At the shinkansen ticket booth, there is a place where you go to buy last-minute seats for about 120$. I went from Tokyo to Kyoto on the express shinkansen like that.  Also, for subway trips within Tokyo, there is a special 2-day pass only available to foreigners that you can only buy in the Bic Camera shop in Shinjuku. It was something like 900Â¥ for 2 days of unlimited Tokyo Metropolitan subway rides.   Nobody ever talks about this, yet they are the cheapest options.

I think the best way to find the cheapest hotel is to look up TripAdvisor and compare prices between different travel agencies.Â Sometimes someÂ agencies like Rakuten and JTB travel have big sales. YouÂ also want to make sureÂ its cancellation policy isÂ realistic before you purchase.Â JAPANiCAN.com often have a terrible cancellation policy. You didn't mention but Agoda often has some insider deals you can't find elsewhere.Â I often find cheaper hotels in Kamata and Shin Yokohama areaÂ whenÂ I want to stayÂ around Tokyo. I suggest foreignÂ travelers to make the best use out of JR pass and go to as many distant cities as possible. Japanese citizen cannot purchase them. It's a privilege for travelers from abroad only. It's fun to explore local cities. You can get reserved seats with no additional costÂ and don't need to feel uncomfortable during the trip. JR trains are quite comfortable.

One problem with hostels is when you get people who snore.  I thought I'd lucked out once in a hostel in Kyoto when my room mates were three young, Japanese women.  I thought for sure with their body types they wouldn't snore.    WRONG.    I was on the top of a bunk bed that shook from how loudly that 5'2 girl snored.  Her companiones were just as loud and sounded like cats were trapped in their throats.  My ear plugs were useless.    Nowadays I stick to capsule hotels or single room hostels.    The other horror of hostels are the infamous plastic-bag packers.  They wake up at the crack of dawn to repack their bags for over two hours -- a constant crinkle, crinkle.  Every item has been individually wrapped in a plastic bag.  It's almost worse than the snoring.

The biggest change I've noticed is Free WiFi has rolled out over a lot of the big cities. Just 4 or 5 years ago, you'd be shocked to find it. Now the bus stops in Kyoto, the subways in Osaka, even places like Himeji castle have free WiFi.

Keep in mind that the night bus may be smaller than you think and your legs may be pinned against the seat in front of you all night. Or in my last case I was sitting in the upper section all the way in the front and my legs were pinned to a steel plate opposed to a cushioned seat.  And not all buses have restrooms on them and the wait between rest stops could be a bit long. That said if you are willing to spend some extra cash and you have plenty of time in advance, I am sure you can find a nice bus that suits you. Consider other options before you settle for the cheapest. You may regret it otherwise.

As a solo traveller, I survived on about 7000 yen per day. This included accomodation, food, tickets and transport (within cities).  However, I did have a JR pass. Basically I went through from Kagoshima (southern tip) to Kyoto (around the central area).  Taking about 1-3 days in interesting prefectures.   way to be real budget: Go to supermarkets for breakfast and lunch. Basically I bought a loaf of bread on sale (500 yen) and i ate one or two pieces each morning for breakfast. For lunch, I'd take something I could eat while walking. I'd thus save time (i could look around and eat) and money (takeaway foods tend to be cheaper). dinner would depend on my spending for the day. Sometimes, I'd have leftovers for souveniors too  staying at guest houses ranged from 1600yen - 3000yen per night.  tickets averaged 600-1200yen.

Decide where you want to go. Try to fit the shinkansen trips in the smallest JR pass window possible (7, 14, 21 days) Add up the fares. It's worth it or not and is usually pretty easy to see.  Bus and airplane are alternatives that can be cheaper but the pass is most convenient for most. Going really far may call for a plane though.

very worth it. because i changed cities every 1-2 days. There was once i started off at Kitakyushu (north part of kyushu), stopped by 2 big stations in Saga and ended my evening off at Hiroshima. All those were covered by the pass.   If I didn't get the rail pass my rail cost would have been in the thousands I believe. The ease and ability to get reserved seats was also a great plus.   If you want to know if its worthit for you, you can get costs for train trips on hyperdia. com and then calculate if its more or less than the rail pass cost

OR, maybe, if you need to cut more on budget, I suggest trying manga cafes. The average price is 500~1500yen, and some places offer a discount if you stay for 10 days straight.  Manga cafes in Japan are designed so that customers have their privacy, which is typically renting an entire room. Some manga cafes in Tokyo and Osaka offers a bed, a bathroom with all neccessities provided (shower, loo, sink... all that hygiene stuff) and of course, huge shelves of manga. So if you're fond of that try looking them up online.

We stayed for a week in Japan was not bad. We are a family of 4. We stayed at a airbnb apartment that cost around $600 dollars for a week.  That is Monday to following Monday.  Food; for breakfast we bought cereal, eggs, milk, etc, For the week. We did spend money on restaurants for lunch or dinner. Depending on our day.  I found restaurants at malls are more expensive than the ones you find on streets. Cokes/sodas are around 3 to 5 dollars in restaurants. Yeah we spend almost 20 dollars once on drinks, after that we decided to get them at the bending machines. They are everywhere and way cheaper. You can also get good food at the supermarkets. They have sushi, salads, veggies, and many more things. I recomend the noodles. We ate there every other day. Come after 6 or 7pm. That's when the food gets a discount, half or more in their price.   Train/metro;  if you will be using the train I recommend buying the passes. I think is more conviniant, and you won't end up with a wallet full of coins.  So only main stations have English maps. Take a pic. Of that map, you will need it. I know there is an app you can use as Well but I don't remember the name.   So this is how it works; Always remember your station name, number and line. Also lines or train have specific colors.  Ex; nin shinjukI station, #29, oedo line. Oedo line is pink. You will see the 29 number in a pink circle.   I hope this made sence.   Money/ credit cards;  With had no problem with our credit card. We let our bank know we were traveling so that we could use our cards. If your bank doesn't have this service I do not know what you can do.  All restaurants and shops accepted our cards. But we did exchange dollars  to yen before comming to Japan.  I do recommend exchanging your dollars. Depending on dollar worth you might get a little more yen!.   For those of you comming from south Korea remember that 800 yen is not almost a won or a dollar. It is almost 10 won/ dollars. I learned this the hard way. ðŸ˜‘   Remember to save money for your way back to airport. Put it aside, so you have it ready for your last day.   Overall I thought Japan was expensive. But if you are comming from USA. It will feel like no change. Everything is pricey, specially for a family. We been in south Korea for a bit and you can do so much more here. The dollar goes a long way. Once you go to Japan come to South Korea, you will love it.

In short, don't tip.  In longer... there are a couple situations where you can or may want to tip, but you don't have to. Nice ryokan (traditional inn), or if you have something like a personal tour guide. Don't give money directly, but in an envelope (Japanese sell a kind, but I think anything would do...). It's done a certain way. If you're intent on doing this, check up on it specifically!  Taxis, you aren't really supposed to tip, but I've heard some have apparently taken it upon themselves to basically take money if you give an amount of money that would be equal to about fare + tip. Taxis are already ridiculously expensive- don't encourage the practice. You don't tip money like this anywhere else in Japan and almost everyone says not to tip taxis.  If you go to a Western place, there may be a service charge that may or may not be included, but I  think I've only seen it once or twice. If you go to a Japanese place like an izakaya there's often a table charge disguised as a small appetizer. But most restaurants don't have this.
jbsantos17 the tipping culture doesn't usually exist in Asia

as a waiter that has to deal with dutch people allot (dutchys dont like to tip), it always makes me happy if you tip even a little even as a gesture, we know people arent made out of money but leaving a few dollars for me can make me pretty happy.

In Japan, they'll think you left extra money by mistake and chase you down.  Or worse, they may be offended.  That's why it's called "culture".  The "right" thing to do can be exactly opposite in different places. That's why you need to research this stuff before you go.
The only time I left a tip during my two week stay in Japan was in a burrito place in Harajuku that had a tip jar on the counter.

Tips  can be considered an insult in many areas so do not do.  It often leads to awkward situations, such as the server running out of the building to catch you on the way out for "accidently" leaving your money on the table.
Since tips aren't the norm, whenever I stay at a hostel, I'll buy extra snacks for the workers. They are always very grateful.

Tips or as the rest of the world would call it American socially pressured bribes, is not a thing in Japan. Workers get paid for their work, and don't get stuffed over like I hear that some people do because their industry incourages short wages due to it. Here in Australia the only places that try to do tipping are restaurants and cafÃ©s, but I don't think its expected, and not an excuse to not pay wages/barely pay.

Btw also take cash. From what I heard last its better as most places don't take cards unless your in a really big place and in the city. But with that crime is pretty low too, so you don't have to worry so much about having it on you.

They were both more or less safe by 1946. Probably even before that.

redfish337 You must not understand how chemistry works. Plutonium, which is the element used in nuclear bombs, has a half life of around 24,000 years. Meaning, it would take that much time for half of the matter to decay. Additionally, radioactive contaminants remain dangerous for up to 20 times the length of their half life. This means that areas contaminated with Plutonium remain dangerous to organisms for almost 500,000 years.

Go take a Geiger counter there. There are videos of it online. It's very likely to be lower than your own house. It's called fallout for a reason- it was an airburst and the small particles blew off over a large area, dissipating down to safe, and at this point, below average, levels.

redfish337 I don't know what reality you are living in, but I have watched plenty of international reports taken in Japan which show that some areas are so flooded with radiation that they are completely unlivable. You must be quite ignorant to assume that 2 atomic bombs and 3 nuclear reactor meltdowns will produce nuclear waste which is "less than my house." If you still don't believe the facts which I state, I will happily find the reports I am referencing for you.

Perhaps some areas of Fukushima, near the reactor. But that's different... and far, far away from Hiroshima anyway. The reactor had far more radioactive material, and was hemorrhaging it at surface level right out into the surrounding area. Fortunately the currents there push most of that out to be diluted down to nothingness in the vast Pacific. But, parts of that area may still be somewhat dangerous. You can't go to the potentially dangerous areas anyway.  Hiroshima and Nagasaki were hit by air blasts meant to maximize blast damage, not radiation. Aside for those immediately affected by high energy particles, there were few long-term aftereffects and the cities are at this point at or below the global radiation average.

Japan wants the yen to drop.  All their car/electronics companies rely on the yen not being extremely strong.
So why the hype of a strong currency? My country is often criticized for its currency's value
It's a balance depending on the buying and selling practices of your country.
Thank you for the information, could you please provide examples of which practices allow a weak currency to provide benefit to a given country's populace?

It lets you make a product for cheaper and increases the relative value of any profit margin, allowing you to undercut foreign competition. And some industries that are profitable one direction are perhaps not profitable in another. A hand-sewn shirt could be made in Sri Lanka and sold in Japan- but the opposite industry would be unprofitable.  Governments have import tariffs, quotas and bans in order to protect their own industries, so there's still a limit to the degree of profit.
