They are... but a lot of the airports are very inconvenient (Fukuoka the main exception) and there are luggage issues, etc when you fly.  When you add everything up, Tokyo/Osaka is about the crossover point. Anywhere farther than that and, JR pass itinerary aside, flying tends to be favorable.  Basically, if you take flights with your full luggage... you have to take a bus or multiple trains pretty far out to an airport, check bags, go through security, take the flight, pick up bags, take another long train or bus to the city center... Even with only a carry-on it's pretty much constant activity on your part without much break. Shinkansen, you pretty much go to the city center station... get on a train, take a break or nap in a nice big seat, and get off at the city center of your destination. The train takes longer than the plane, but the whole procedure is about even, and for the shinkansen you can just relax the whole way. So, yeah, check your options!

I have a recommandation! If you want to go to kyoto and watch all the shrines there (there are many of them) and also want to finish watching them, you will really need a taxi. But a normal taxi is way too expensive for such things. So the best and cheapest way to travel among kyotos shrines is to use the "seki taxi". They are far cheaper (about 50% less then you'd travel with a normal taxi)and also organize everything really carefully (for egsample in wihich order you visit the shrines and so on). Of course they do not ppan everything for you. You need to request in advance which shrines you want to visit and where you want to eat your lunch. I used it an it was really great. If you want they also can guide you around!

There is another, potentially cheaper, way to find inexpensive accommodation, especially if you're traveling in a group. I went to Japan for 9 days last August, and through a website (not AirBnB), we found a person advertising an apartment for rent in Harjuku. The apartment had four beds and space for two or three more futons to be rolled out onto the floor, so potentially seven people could wedge their way in relatively comfortably. The price was under $80.00 per day, which was split among the group of us. We're planning another trip next spring, and the price for the same place still hasn't appreciably changed.

AverageGamerWill you don't... you can literally point. Or  use your japanese dictionary if stuck. Most of our trip we said arigatou (gozaimasu) and "tsu" (two) when buying tickets, but not even that was needed. We tried talking to the locals about non tourist things by using our almost random anime japanese and people understood us. XD i guess you might need "___ doko desu ka? ( where is ___?) But most likely if you dont have an offline map and the place is far away, they wont be able to help you. They might say "yamanote" and you better know how to find a yamanote train line. Have a dictionary and a map offline on your phone. Even better, get yourself a wifi subscription or dongle from the hotel/hostel.   Edit: oh and "ikura" might be useful for when you want to pay for something.

My favorite tip for cheap eats is waiting until supermarkets "sticker" their prepared food usually 7pm or later (varies by chain). They'll put a discount sticker on the day's food to clear it out so it doesn't go to waste. You can get bentos, karaage (fried chicken), and even sushi for 30-60% off. And it's usually decent food not gas station junk.

My biggest tip is if you want to go to a nice restaurant then go at lunch time. They normally do a lunch special which is pretty cheap compared to their dinner prices and super tasty. Then for dinner time you can go somewhere cheap like sukiya or just get a 711 bentou. I managed to travel for 3 months from Okinawa to Sapporo spending Â¥400,000 or $4000 for the whole time including food Accomodation travel and tourist attractions (starting and ending in Yamaguchi so this includes flights from/to there) The south (Kyushu and Okinawa) is much cheaper than the North because they have cheaper and more choice of hostels and a fantastic bus system so I spent half of the time there and the other half traveling the main island and Hokkaido in the North I bought multiple Seishun 18 Kinpu (a ticket for local trains which you can use  in the main tourist/holiday seasons) and traveled that way which is good to do if you have a little more time to travel as it can take sometimes 3 times longer to get somewhere rather than using the Shinkansen but it's great to use if you want to go to multiple places on the same day along a specific route (make sure to avoid the rush hour if you're traveling with a backpack or everyone will hate you)

Where did you stay in hostels? A lot of hostels in Japan have beds with multiple walls and a curtain or door. It may be one step above the cheapest option (like an extra 200-300 yen/night), but it feels pretty private. These are pretty similar to capsules, but usually lack a TV and are a lot larger so you can sit up easily, move around and more easily stow more of your stuff in your area. True capsule hotels usually aren't very social. I'd suggest getting something more private in a hostel if you want to meet other travelers.
redfish337 I was in London Paris and Amsterdam when I was using a hostel.  I see what you are saying though that sounds like the best option.
Also, the night bus can be a really really uncomfortable experience. The rail pass is an amazing opportunity to see Japan. Check out hitchhiking too. It's way more common in Japan.

Indeed, night bus is hit or miss unless you sleep like a log... and then you better be able to get up and off in time if you're not getting off at the final stop. About every other turns the heat on to sauna levels and sleeping is hopeless.
Assuming you're a visa treaty country, immigration just wants your first address and maybe a phone number for it. They don't care about anything else.
redfish337 is the US in that treaty?
Yes, US is a visa treaty country with Japan.

McDonalds accepts credit cards from this summer.

Most decent restaurants, bars and izakayas accept credit cards for dinner, but not for lunch ( unless it is an expensive lunch ). Most cheap diners, fast food and cafes don't.  It isn't very common to use or accept credit cards for low priced stuff. Let's say that if your bill is less than 1500 yens, then it is very probable that they won't accept credit card payment.  A cheap meal is bento (box lunch). There are special stores like Origin Bento, or you can find them in some cheap diners too. A bento in a convenience store is cheap, but in a Supermarket it is even cheaper, so if you can, go to a supermarket. And most supermarkets accept credit cards.  And, you also have a manga kissaten as an alternative for a place to stay for one night. A manga kissaten is a place where you can read all the manga (in japanese) you want, watch TV, use a computer, internet, etc for a fixed fee that can be per hour or per night. They have individual rooms with padded floor and a couch, and usually with enough space to sleep. You can also use the shower room. Most people use this in the night when they miss the last train.

I only bring it up because they are one of the most technologically advanced societies in the world, yet they still do stuff that is considered by many to be old and outdated.

The charge that the stores have to pay for every credit card transaction is quite expensive and the money deposit has a few days delay so that's why small business don't want to accept cards for small transactions, they will be losing money. I don't know how stores abroad deal with this but that's why some stores here will give you less discount or points if you use a credit card or just simply don't accept.  And it is true that some business like real state or foodstuffs still use fax. Usually managed by old people who haven't adapted to modern methods or can't use or don't want to invest in a computerized solution. You have young people always trying to use the most advanced solution and old people using what they think is safest and require less changes or learning. And I think that's true for every country, not only Japan.  If you don't have enough money, you can leave a document or something valuable, go to an ATM, and go back to the store to pay and get your documents back. Just to be sure, ask if they accept cards before you order.
Why is that though?

You can definitely withdraw from ATMs using your international credit/debit cards, but not all of them. And some machines do not have English language option. I thought I already know enough Japanese but one time, I unknowingly blocked my card! Also, it depends on where you're travelling but ATMs are not 24 hrs operational, except the ones you find in convenience stores.
7-11 and Japan Post ATMs except international cards.

People aren't concerned with cards often in Japan, because robbery almost NEVER happens, and people will actually pick up your money and hand it back to you.   People carry large ammounts of cash around all the time, its perfectly safe there.

We live in a modern world where the new and old co exist ...i think there has been a misconception about Japan through the media or other sources...Yes they maybe the leading nations in mechanization (Robotics to be specific) but it's unrealistic to assume that can and has been applied everywhere. Technology has it's limitations. Japan, like many other countries, has a rich cultural history, and while progress is being made in one area...in other areas some aspects of conservatism are still being practiced.

Hey Chris, I watched your videos and visited Japan for the first time last year during Hanami. Travelled Tokyo (day trips to Kamakura and Toshigi shrine) -> Osaka (Kyoto was booked so did day trips there and also to Nara) -> Hiroshima (Day trip to Miyajima).  Travelled alone, stayed in hostels - sort of lonely but very memorable. Ate lots of Japanese cuisines, sometimes at Yoshinoya too. I had a Japan rail pass and I can say if you aren't much into saving money, Shinkansen is very convenient and comfortable. Once I travelled 4 hours back from Osaka to Tokyo to get my Camera SD card repaired (but couldn't get it repaired and lost half of my photos). But the most memorable journey was waking up at 4:30 AM near Miyajima and then catching the 6 AM Shinkansen for a 6 HOUR continuous trip NON-STOP from Hiroshima-shin to Tokyo Station!! Ate Eki-bentos like a King and took pictures of Mount Fuji. I stayed at Narita for a day, in the evening I learned that the very next when I had to catch my flight back home, they had Taiko Drum festival!! The house I was staying at, the owner was spear martial artist and I met two gentlemen from Scandinavia who were studying Sword styles from a nearby school. The even had Katanas wrapped in nice velvet cloth!!  I really miss Japan and hope to return as soon as possible!!

Love hotels are just hotels that specialize in short-term logging and typically include a lot of porn channels or sex toys. You can also sometimes buy longer term rooms but they tend to cost extra to make up for the fact that they could probably get a more overall money from a bunch of quicky couples than one person renting for the a few days.  Only the sleezy illegal ones double as brothals, so you have to bring your own playmate.  In Japan it's MUCH more common to have small houses that you share with extended family, so a lot of younger people tend to prefer to go to a love hotel to have some privacy if the house isn't suitably large enough to get it at home.

Many good points Chris. Before you think I'm a hater, I'd like to say great video and I agree with virtually all your points... except, the night bus. I tried it and will never try it again. Could NOT sleep on the damn bus and what should have been a 6 hour ride turned into an 8 hour ride with what the Japanese bus driver referred to as "toilet time" every hour or so. Yes, they spent about 20 minutes trying to explain the bathroom break schedule (or as Britts say, "sh-eh-jew-l") before they finally mustered up the phrase "toilet time". Granted, that was the highlight of the ride, I arrived to my hostel with my jet lag reincarnated. Yes, if you're on a very tight budget, this is an option (especially if you're a deep sleeper) but you should also consider the fact that you have a limited time in Japan. Don't waste a hours or in my case, a whole day. The last two times I went, I used the Shinkansen.  Worth every penny. P.S. No mention of Saizeriya? That place rocks if you're on a budget <3

Overall, this is a VERY useful guide.  1. Capsule hotels + business hotels all the way. $50/night for a capsule hotel is a bit too much in my opinion, but those are on the really high end. I stayed in one that is further from the center of Tokyo and it cost me ~$30/night. There were a few hostels and business hotels in Osaka from ~$20/night. Also, the longer you book, the price should be better.  2. Conbini stores are awesome. $2-3 for a breakfast.  3. Local metro passes for $10 per day (in Tokyo for example) are a pretty good deal too.   P.S. @Abroad in Japan: have you ever tried hitchhiking or camping?

Two weeks for my husband and I, with our shitty Canadian dollar wasn't bad at all. All prices are in Canadian dollar.  > Air Flight from Toronto to Osaka; $1,200 round trip for two ( we were super lucky and traveling during the quiet tourist months.) AIRBNB was the best thing for us. We were able to choose really really awesome places, close to main train lines, and made sure we could get Free Poket WifI from each AirBnb we stayed at so we didn't need to purchase our own.  > 2 nights 3 days in Osaka, $200 > 2 nights 3 days in Kyoto, $200 > 9 nights 8 days in Tokyo; $750 (most expensive, staying right on a main train line.) > JR Rail Pass; bought the 7 day pass since in Osaka and Kyoto its rather useless; roughly $450ish total for both of us. Which paid for itself while being in Tokyo and going from Kyoto to Tokyo alone.  > Two SUICA cards; only put about $40 each on each card and didn't need to refill it. I still have $5 left on each card.  > Spending money we took for food, things we wanted, ect. Split between the two of us; $2,000 + VISA cards if needed (which we never used.) Came back to Canada with $500 in our pocket still.  We were still able to eat really awesome food for cheap. We had this absolutely amazing Katsu in Kyoto that I will never forget. As well, we planned our vacation March and left in November. We payed off ALL the trip before going and came back with 0 debt. Doing that, we were able to save money on the side and make sure that we weren't still paying off the trip months later.
I went with 2 friends last year, we spent 2000-2300â‚¬ each for 21 days in total (flights included). Quite cheap for an outstanding trip.

A Manga-cafe is a great place to sleep if you don't have a reservation. Usually under 20$ for 8-12h including hot drinks and a PC. Also over TripAdvisor I found enough hostels starting at 10$ a night, and enough capsule hotels starting at 15$ all over Japan. One capsule hotel in Tokyo I can recommend is Capsule Value Kanda. I payed 12â‚¬ a night, and it is 1 stop from Akihabara and Tokyo station. Also very nice and clean, with a traditional Japanese bath. Thought the capsules are a bit older. In Kyoto I stayed in a private double room with a friend for 10â‚¬ a person (20â‚¬ in total) per night. The place was called small world guest house. It was a bit far from the city centre and the room was tiny, but it was still good, and the building was a very old traditional Japanese House.

@Durrr Annn I wouldn't recommend a Manga cafe to live in, but it is cheaper than $20 a night, more like $12 probably, and $20 for 24 hours.  But there is no way you can get a $500 apartment fully furnished in Tokyo. Not unless you are in a very small station in the far west side of Tokyo that is like at least 2  or 3 hours by train from any of the core 23 wards of Tokyo.  Usually the cheapest apartment without a single piece of furniture, inside the 23-ku should be around $550 if it is pretty far from the station (15 or more minutes by walk), or in a very far and cheap ward / district. And that's very cheap. And usually you have to pay a gratitude fee (usually 1 month rent), and you can't easily rent if you are a foreigner without a guarantor.  Fully furnished apartments in any of the main Tokyo areas should be at least $900. And very small ones.

I don't remember the exact area where it was because I don't have the website open anymore, but it was very small and said it was in the middle of the town and listed 'walk to' locations. It was also a website specifically made for foreigners looking for housing while they are in Japan, hence why I could certainly find cheaper if I lived there.
It'd really be nice to have capsule hotels in NA or Europe, as is there's only hostels for $30-50/night and while they're great, it'd be nice to have a private spot to sleep in, however small.

Durrr Annn These are normal so called Share Houses. They are so cheap because you get a smallâ€‹ private room in a multi room flat, that you share with other people. My friend lives in one of these. They also don't get taken care off well, so the one my friend stays in has rats and cockroaches, and everything is old and falling apart. It's also right besides the tracks. Because of this, and the risk of getting kicked out, if the owner wants to rent the room to someone else at a higher price or other stuff, I really wouldn't recommend living in one, tho they are often conviently located.

I've visited twice on my own in January 2016 and 2017 for Tokyo Auto Salon. To give you a basic run down. I payed Â£420 return flight from my local airport Cardiff to Tokyo via Amsterdam with KLM. My two weeks accommodation cost me around Â£600 for a 4* business hotel next to Shinjuku station (The city center), great hotel and will be returning there again next year. I must have spent around Â£150 on train tickets and taxi rides for two weeks, reasonably cheap considering I was traveling in the capital and made a few trips out of Tokyo. Food and drink is the same price as back home but of much better quality so I didn't really care what I was spending so can't help you there. And finally spending money was where I went all in, I easily spend Â£1000 on import car parts, days out, snacks and shopping. Its not as expensive as most people let on but you can easily spend all your money within the first week if you're not carefully, there is something for everyone in Japan. An quick way to save money if you plan on visiting Tokyo though is to stay in chiba prefecture, it is next to Tokyo and is a quick train ride away.

I just realized the place near Shinjuku is called "Piss Alley" - the shops/restaurants inside are apparently nothing special, but the rates I saw there were the best I saw in Japan. There's no trick, just go to the ATM and withdraw money.  Works best if you get a card without foreign transaction fees. ATMs typically have the best exchange rates and even if they have fees it works out to less than exchanging at a money changer or bank or gold shop.

If you're flying domestically from or to some local airport in Japan that's only served by JAL or ANA, you can still get some rather cheap flights as a foreign visitor if you have an international flight ticket by any airline to or from Japan. Check out ANA's Experience Japan Fare (10800 Yen for up to 5 domestic flights per international ticket, some routes for half the price) or JAL's Japan Explorer Pass (Again up to 5 domestic flights per international ticket, prices range between 5400 and 10800 Yen).

Helpful video! :) I am currently travelling solo through Japan on a student budget, and here are my experiences on accommodation and travel:  Accommodation: In contrast to Chris, I've found AirB&B to almost always be the cheapest option, the occasional competitor being hostels I've found with the Agoda-app, which seems to be a popular one here. Also, try couchsurfing,its 0Â¥!  Travel: If you have even the slightest inclination and are not on a very strict schedule, I suggest hitchhiking. Japan is by far the easiest country I've hitchhiked in, the people are so friendly and willing to help. It helps a lot if you can somewhat bridge the language barrier with Japanese skills, you get to meet a lot of interesting people.  Also keep an eye out for airline special offers, I managed to get a Peach airline ticket from Kansai to Sapporo for 3000Â¥. I agree with nightbuses being great for value, but much less so if you can't sleep in them, and spend your holiday all groggy because of it.

DaveTrippin these days? Itâ€™s always been the same... you need to burn more than youâ€™re putting in. Pretty simple, just eat healthier and smaller meals and be more active

It's not exercise... Exercise barely doesn't do anything. It's all about the food you eat.  The body uses carbohydrates as the first energy source and only when those are depleted, fat is burned to be used for energy. So if you want to lose fat, you have to reduce your intake of carbohydrates. That's why the low-carb diet works so well.

I always try to go to bed hungry. If I'm not hungry when I go to bed it means I ate too much at dinner. When I wake in the morning I'm not (very) hungry. So I just eat a couple small meals during the day before going to sleep again at night. (The first week or two of this way of eating can be hell but eventually you get used to it.)

Another option for train travel is the Suica (or the other variations) especially if you're leaving from the same airport. It's a reloadable train card where you don't need to buy tickets constantly and automatically deducts the trip from your balance. (Like the Melbourne MYki card in Australia, or the Opal card in the UK). Also, if you arrive and leave at the same airport, you can actually return your suica card and get the amount you paid for it refunded.

Thanks for the great vid! Whenever people tell me they want to travel to Japan but are afraid that they will have to spend lots and lots of money I ask them what they want to do/see, how much luxury they need and if they are willing to spend nights in hostels, eat in cheap restaurants, try new things.  I travel to Japan a lot and in my experience it totally depends on what level of comfort you need. For example, if I don't have that much money to spend I try to stay in hostels or cheaper business hotels, eat in small shops off the main roads and touristy districts, buy stuff at 100 Yen shops or those cheap drugstores. If you speak at least a bit of Japanese then it's way way easier I have to admit.  You may also spend less if you ride busses or night trains than the Shinkansen, but it will take you a lot longer to reach your destination.  On the other hand I think that most tourists want to see "the Japan" they envisioned, try sushi places, shop in malls like 109, buy nice souveniers and sleep in hotels that they feel comfortable in and have more or less western standards. Honestly I don't think that it's a bad thing especially if it's your first time in Japan and everybody has to know for themselves how they like to travel. I think the most important thing is that you have fun, enjoy the trip and make lots of good memories.

Don't knock the skateboard! I bought one the second day of my trip and it saved my feet. The first day was 18 days of walking around and taking it all in. The second day was cruising around on my Sector 9 long board taking in the sights at such a better pace. Also, I can't wait to go back!  Over the course of 27 days split in Tokyo/osaka/Kyoto I spent a total of about $3800 US counting my $1400 plane ticket.   In average, I spent about $75 a day on food/drink but I never passed something I wanted to try.   It helped that I had about 7 free nights at the Hyatts out there, the rest of my time was spent in capsules. The capsules save you a ton of money and are incredibly clean.

Me and my buddy arranged our complete trip via JTB travels, but people who want to sort everything themselves might struggle with Ryokan since, as far as i know, not many foreigners bother with them (yet). If you are traveling in a larger group (more than 4 people), you probably will have trouble finding restaurants. In this case izakayas are a great and cheap option, although you might need to reserve a table in advance.Â As for sushi, there are a couple of 100Â¥ conveyer belt sushi chains. Just make sure you don't go to these places when you are already hungry as they are quite popular and you can wait for like 30-45 min to actually get seated (at least in Tokyo).Another option for a quick cheap lunch is street food.

Hi there,  Just a reminder here that JR Pass DOES NOT COVER LOCAL SUBWAYS. It only works with trains, buses or ferries operated by JR. As local subways are not run by JR. I bought JR Pass before I arrived in Japan then realised it was waste of money as I wasn't going to trancelike intercity frequently.  My advice here is, unless you are visiting multiple cities ACROSS HONSHU on Shinkansen (not just one trip from Kansai to Tokyo or just around Kansai), don't get the JR Pass.

If you don't do the rail pass for the shinkansen I would recommend buying non reserved tickets. You are not limited to a specific departure time and you can get "buddy buddy" with some Japanese people! (That's how I met my friend Shinya who also lives in Hiroshima.) Now in turn for metro and subway. Since living here I have bought an ICOCA and SUICA cardsÂ (depending where I am at) which costs 500 yen and you can put as much money as you need on them. For 6 days in Tokyo doing nothing but traveling by metro I spent close to 3,000 yen in total on the card. Also if you are traveling to Shinjuku station I would recommend Yakitori Alley near the station. You average dinnerÂ would be around 800 yen for one person.Â There you will find dozens of shops each with a unique style and experience down a narrow but beautiful alley away from the lights that has the smell of grilled food pouring out of every shop.

You don't need to completely plan your trip out and book your overnight stays 3 months in advance. I travelled one month trough Japan last year in July and booked every accomdation on the evening before going there. This way I was able to just do and go wherever I wanted to and change my plans on the fly. I think it was still quite cheap. I payed around 30 to 50â‚¬ per night for a single room plus bathroom. Only Tokyo was a bit more pricy with around 60 - 80â‚¬ a night (but that was also over the weekend, prices seem to be higher on the weekends). In total I spend a little bit less than 3.000â‚¬ for one month in Japan  including the Plane trickets (Germany - Tokyo) and the Railpass which was defenetly worth it's price.

We seen most of the popular places in Tokyo in about 3 days. First the east: Shinjuku, Meiji, Shibuya, Tokio Tower and the near temple, dinner back in yakitori alley in shinjuku (You should also see the shinjuku area at night); Second day the south and center: Tsukiji market (also to have breakfast there), Ginza, the parks of the Imperial Palace, lunch in Tokio Station, Akihabara; The third day the north: Skytree, Asakusa, Ueno, and we eventually went also to Akihabara. The 4th and 5th we stayed in Tokyo there we decided to go visit Nikko and Kamakura as one day excursions (We had the JR pass for later in the trip so this was "free" and a good oportunity to see more of Japan). It is easier and cheaper to reach Kamakura. Its closer and there is no need for bullet trains. I recommend here to stop at kita-kamakura station and go downhill to the beach while visiting interesting temples along the way. Then we went to Osaka to see Kyoto and more ...  Anyway, you should definetly buy the "Tokyo Subway Ticket" 72-hour (1500 yen). It gives you total freedom in the two subways of tokio and avoids losing time buying tickets. There are also 48 and 24 hour variants.  A tip if you don't want to spend money in the Skytree is to go up the top floors (level ~30 or so) of the near shopping mall or to visit the free Tokyo goverment building observation decks. Also, a nice restaurant we went is Uobei Sushi in Shibuya. Good price, tourist friendly and fun.

Go to Tsukiji.  Try the Sushi Zanmai conveyor-belt sushi restaurant there.  Walk to the Hamarikyu Gardens and have a look around.  Catch the ferry there and go to Asakusa.  Make a reservation beforehand and eat at the Sky Restaurant 634 in the Skytree.  It's a little pricy, we paid about 5000 yen each, but you get a great meal and you can skip the lines at the elevators.

I only used about 10 phrases off the top of my head, and they were so friendly and tried their best to be patient with me, sometimes when I was lost, they would guide me to the place, one guy even left his post and ran after me to tell me I was going in the wrong direction! xD all in all, I think it was fine, maybe next time I'd study a bit more but you don't have to worry!

When I went to Japan, I used broken Japanese, lots of hand gestures and "sumimasen", "arigatoo gozaimasu", and "nihongo wakarimasen". Funnily enough, when I spoke with broken Japanese and used hand gestures, they were much more relaxed than if I didn't speak any at all. The point is to get the message across. Pointing to a place on a map and saying "doko" is just as effective as asking in perfect Japanese where a place is.
Josef Mengele and if all else fails, 'Sumimasen' and 'Arigatou gozaimasu' are the only phrases you need. xD

Thanks everyone for giving me helpful advice! What website would you guys recommend where I could learn some short Japanese phrases like simple communicative words and etc?
I use Memrise for basic learning. It's free,  and has a bunch of lessons. Chris mentioned iTalki on his video before, if you want to learn by talking to a Japanese native over Skype.

Don't limit yourself! They're pretty good at speaking English. And yeah, it seems lazy not to at least try, but don't set yourself up for a goal like becoming fluent and push your travel years away just for that.  Might I suggest getting a phrase book and memorizing both things you can say and also what the response may be? A good phrase book is the Making Out series, "Making Out in Japanese" and "More Making Out in Japanese". They teach you the way the actual Japanese people talk, using slang and shortcut terms instead of textbook Japanese (I'm pretty sure. It's been a couple of years since I looked at it, but I know my impression was favourable). I think there's also another phrase book I have that teaches you what to say and what the person will say back (such as when dining out). I'll let you know the title if I find it.
You really need it at all if your in a big city like Tokyo or Osaka. Some basics like please and thank you can't hurt though.

Yes and no. It all depends where you live. I work in a very rural town that is split when it comes to foreigners, if you do travel with a group into places like this I recommend having a friend or yourself,Â whom is able to speak some Japanese. Worse comes to worse you can use google translate but I would advise against it. Other than that the closer you get to the city the more you will see people who are friendlier towards foreigners.   Another interesting thing is that with English being taught in school, children and young adults want to test their English skills on you. They are also very curious of the outside world and want to learn more about it. In time and with the push by the Japanese government to start children learning English at younger ages you will start to see the youth of Japan become a bilingual generation.

I.B.  In my experience, touring around Japan for over 20 years, I have only run into ONE less than awesomely polite experience.  That was when I entered an izakaya at midday and encountered a grandfather who was leaving.  He muttered something a little less than polite, doubtless assuming I would not understand.  To be fair, he was of the age that he probably fought in WWII, so it was understandable.   Anyway, when I addressed him using keigo (very polite Japanese), as one should when addressing elders in Japan, he was shocked and hastily excused himself.   I guess my point is, if you are polite and respectful of Japanese culture you will very rarely run into anything less than an amazing welcome anywhere in Japan.

Abroad in Japan A Manga-cafe is a great place to sleep if you don't have a reservation. Usually under 20$ for 8-12h including hot drinks and a PC. Also over TripAdvisor I found enough hostels starting at 10$ a night, and enough capsule hotels starting at 15$ all over Japan. One capsule hotel in Tokyo I can recommend is Capsule Value Kanda. I payed 12â‚¬ a night, and it is 1 stop from Akihabara and Tokyo station. Also very nice and clean, with a traditional Japanese bath. Thought the capsules are a bit older. In Kyoto I stayed in a private double room with a friend for 10â‚¬ a person (20â‚¬ in total) per night. The place was called small world guest house. It was a bit far from the city centre and the room was tiny, but it was still good, and the building was a very old traditional Japanese House.

Even in Tokyo you could get a solid 1 bedroom hotel for around 50 USD. I could rough it in a hostel or capsule hotel for even cheaper, or opt for an airbnb. I've seen them as low as 15-20 dollars. For transportation, if you're going around the country then a Japan Rail Pass is a no-brainer. But per day in Tokyo I was spending 10-15 USD on trains, and maybe 20~ on food. Both of these costs could have dropped if I walked more (I was already doing 10+ miles a day on foot) and I was at times buying snacks/etc. If you really wanted to ball on a budget, you could do Tokyo for a week for 650 USD round trip (with layover/connection I just flew into Tokyo from Newark for 750 round trip in the middle of July via Air Canada) and allocate 75 dollars a day for food, hostel/capsule or airbnb and public transit. So all in all with airfare included you could do Tokyo for just shy of 1,200 USD.

I spent about $2000 not counting plane tix on my trip last October, which was a goodly 2 1/2 weeks in Tokyo -> Kyoto -> Osaka. Probably about half of that was room/transportation/tourist fees and I spent the rest on food and late night drinking (I developed a taste for cheap combini enabled oolong highballs). We got the 14 JR pass for convenience and I can vouch for Airbnb being a very viable option for a group of four or more. We got a quiet apartment in Asakusa next to Sensoji Temple and an elementary school so every morning was punctuated by the sound of bells and pleasant school chimes. In Kyoto we splurged a little and got an entire three story house (with a full bath setup, very nice) to ourselves right next to the Kamogawa central area so everything was within walking distance. In Osaka, the apartment was pretty small but it was also right next to the Dotonburi strip and Kuromon Market so I ate myself to ruin. No regrets.
Abroad in Japan Hey! I really want to visit Japan one day and want to learn the language. But is English used a lot in Japan? (Just curiosity)

You probably shouldn't expect most people to understand English fluently but in the major cities, you can get by in most tourist interactions with a phrase book/app and an apologetic bow. Ordering food for example, you can often ask for a English menu (eigo no menu wa arimasu ka?) and learning to count for people and for food items goes a long way. Subway and train stations also have plenty of romaji and English phrase signage for tourists in major cities so as long as you pay attention and give yourself time to acclimate to the reality that they will be punctual even if you are not, you can get by.

My biggest tip is if you want to go to a nice restaurant then go at lunch time. They normally do a lunch special which is pretty cheap compared to their dinner prices and super tasty. Then for dinner time you can go somewhere cheap like sukiya or just get a 711 bentou. I managed to travel for 3 months from Okinawa to Sapporo spending Â¥400,000 or $4000 for the whole time including food Accomodation travel and tourist attractions (starting and ending in Yamaguchi so this includes flights from/to there) The south (Kyushu and Okinawa) is much cheaper than the North because they have cheaper and more choice of hostels and a fantastic bus system so I spent half of the time there and the other half traveling the main island and Hokkaido in the North I bought multiple Seishun 18 Kinpu (a ticket for local trains which you can use  in the main tourist/holiday seasons) and traveled that way which is good to do if you have a little more time to travel as it can take sometimes 3 times longer to get somewhere rather than using the Shinkansen but it's great to use if you want to go to multiple places on the same day along a specific route (make sure to avoid the rush hour if you're traveling with a backpack or everyone will hate you)

We spent two weeks in Japan this year with the 2nd week falling on Golden Week, so things weren't exactly 'cheap'. However, we did get what I think are nice deals at the business hotels as you mentioned. In particular, we stayed at the Tokyo Hotel Mystays in Asakusabashi (right next to Asakusabashi station) and at the Kyoto Hotel Mystays near Shijo station. Nice clean hotels, very helpful staff. We're not much for fancy food so we did as you suggested and we were eating breakfasts from the selections at Lawsons, 7/11, Fresco, FamilyMart, etc. I tended to go for ramen a lot when we ate out simply because I wanted real ramen, not what we generally get in the US. Oddly, I miss the cheap treats at 7/11 a lot. While we ended up spending about $2000 US on hotels for the whole trip we didn't spend a cent on air travel because of frequent flyer miles.

if you're in japan for a long time and in certain periods the seishun 18 kippu is amazing. it's something like 15 days that don't need to be done sequentially i.e. most JR passes are for a period of time say 14 days and if you only take a train on day 1 and day 14 you pass is still expired, whereas this ticket goes by days used and it comes out to something crazy like 2000 yen a use and you can use all none fast trains in essence (i can't recall if it also gives you free busses or not). so the trips take a super long time but it's really cheap and you end up seeing some interesting places.

CamWattsYourProblem the ticket is five days of travel and it has a limit on the time period of use but it's not as short as the jr pass (sometimes upwards of a month) and times when you can buy it they are normally available around new year, Sakura season and the summer holidays.

@CammWatts: Remember that the JRPass also gets you in the majority of the commuter trains in the bigger cities like Tokyo and Osaka; that's a real convenience to not have to figure out the correct ticket price to purchase rather than just being admitted to the station. Using those trains to get around will eat several dollars every day. Also, the JRPass tickets come in one week durations (7-day, 14-day, 21-day). The cost for a 7-day JRPass is almost identical to the price of a round trip shinkansen ticket from Tokyo to Osaka. So, you only need one decent sized side trip each week to more than pay for the cost of the pass. But, if you're going to get a pass, I'd advise making the most of it. We're planning a two week trip to Japan next year where we'll spend a week based in Tokyo and a week based in Osaka. We're planning day trips to Fuji, Nagano, Himeji, Hiroshima, Kyoto, etc., not counting the round trip between Tokyo and Osaka. Bought piecemeal, these trips would cost well over $1000 USD; the two weeks JRPass is about $600.

I went to Japan last month, and I spent in total 2000 usd or around Â£1550 for accomodation transport, food, souvenir and tickets for universal studio and disneysea. my destinations: osaka, nara, kobe, kyoto, then tokyo I bought 2 separate ticket, from my home country to osaka, and for returning home ticket from tokyo to my home country (saves a lot of time and money if you know where do you wanna go first)   IMO, if you wanna travel really cheap, they have kansai through pass which costs 5000 yen for 3 days. it covers all non jr train in kansai area which are: osaka, kyoto nara, kobe, etc (also cover buses).  kyoto has their own city pass costs 2000 yen for 3 days and covers all buses and non jr train inside kyoto (do take bus there, kyoto is beautiful) tokyo has their own city railway ticket, which costs 1500 yen for 3 days (not including bus I think) the main problem is.. jr train has the most strategic stations in all cities that I went. for example jr station will have their station right in the middle of akihabara, while non jr one needs like 5 mins walking to center akihabara. but the do much cheaper, so..  for food, Imo, it is your loss if you don't try some interesting food there, but yeah, I usually buy my breakfast in advance, such as onigiri or instant ramen in convenient store  lastly, dessert and souvenirs are expensive there, try to hold back a bit for it if you are on budget, or, buy souvenirs in daisho (all 108 yen unless stated) they have interesting items.. from food and drinks, souvenir, to beauty products, to party props, and many games (such as nano blocks, magic trick, etc)  and based on my experience: surprisingly, I found out that it is cheaper to buy drinks from vending machine than convenient store

The vending machines are ubiquitous. If one seems slightly more pricey than usual, just walk a few blocks down to the next one or so and it'll probably be several yen cheaper depending on locale and rotation. I found myself hitting the Dekavita C energy drinks hard whenever I needed a pick me up on a long day of walking around.

Best way to fly from SFO is direct to NRT, hands down. Don't settle for connection layover flights, they're a trap and waste your time and patience more than the money they save since oftentimes, they'll end up flying directly over Japan on the way to the connection hub and then you'll spend another 2-3 hours flying back.  That being said, you'll be looking at anywhere from 800-1k after fees and taxes unless you score a heck of a deal or have the flexibility to fly standby.

One of my tips for finding accommodation on a budget is to talk to the friendly people at JR Tours in the major train stations.  I haven't been back to Japan in a while, but when I went, wifi wasn't freely available enough to be useful, and anything online usually involved finding an internet cafe.  JR Tours will let you know what the cheapest rates are for however many nights you will be staying anywhere, can reserve the place for you, and give you a map to get there.  That said, I do recommend the business hotels, as I can't sleep on a moving vehicle.    Also, when you buy food at a convenience store, they will often ask you if you want it warmed.  You can ask them to warm anything in the microwave behind the counter.

I can second this. Me and some friends went to Japan for two weeks this summer and got an AirBnB in Shinjuku for approximately $31 per person per night. It was a private apartment with 4 beds, a washing machine and our own bathroom. It was small but very clean and had airco (a must during the hot and humid summer months). It had self check-in so it was very convenient regarding arrival time. After that we got a guest house in Kyoto for about $29.5 per person per night. Two bedrooms with comfy futons, a nice living room, washing machine again, small kitchen... Shop around on booking sites and you can get excellent deals. As for food, with a bit of research and Yelp/Google Maps work you'll find fantastic options for good prices, and the 24/7 convenience stores will have you covered for breakfast and basic necessities.

Me and my husband just recently finally got to go to Japan albeit just for 12 days and we only stuck to Tokyo and Kyoto, because we rather wanted to chill at fewer places than spending most of our time commuting to destinations and changing Hotels. We went off season and didn't find our trip any more expensive than doing city trips to any other larger cities. We were quite surprised the trip turned out a lot less expensive than we had expected.  We opted for budget hotels at around 80 to 90 Euros a night, both quite central and perfectly connected via metro. If we had been still in our 20s we might have gone for even cheaper options (hostels and capsules) which were also available in plenty around our travel time (late November, early December). But in your late 30s you kind of appreciate a bit more privacy and can afford it. We used the JR Rail pass for our commute from and to Narita. You are right, that airport is a pain to get to and from, but with NEX which is included in the JR pass it was both easy and comfortable and the flights to Narita were a whole lot cheaper than to Haneda. As we were also planning to go to Kyoto via Shinkansen (Hikari line is also covered by JR Rail Pass) it fit together perfectly that way. As for commuting within cities we got ourselves two Welcome Suica cards at the airport (I think this tourist version is pretty new) and charged 5000 yen on each of them. We used it extensively both in Tokyo and Kyoto and still had each 1000 yen left at the end of our trip, so we could have even charged it with less. We only used cabs four times, that is to get from Tokyo/Kyoto station to our Hotel and back with our luggage and our hotels were always close enough that it was never more than 2000 yen. As for food, it was literally just like European prices, you go for pricey food you get a 100 Euro bill, you go for down to earth cheap food you get a 15 euro bill. Towards the end we really tried hard to spend our coin that we had brought along in cash on souvenirs and gifts, unwilling to exchange our yen back and lose more in the process. We still ended up taking quite a few bills back home with us. Now we're saving them in hopes we'll get to go to Japan some time again.  Seriously, we live in Mumbai, I am originally from Munich, we also lived in San Francisco and Santiago de Chile before, also we traveled to Paris, Madrid, London, New York and other comparable cities. At least as long as you stick to well connected bigger cities Japan is really not more expensive than any other bigger city worldwide. Frankly, as for food we felt prices were on perfectly European level. Mumbai and San Francisco can be way more expensive in that regard. Commuting was easily cheaper than Munich both with cab or metro. Hotel prices also were on average European level. But again, mind we came really off season. I am sure for Hanami and the likes you'll be shelling out triple for accommodation. Else it really depends on how high you want to spend. If need be you can eat very cheap (like Ramen was a go to for us, cheap and fills you up good. wouldn't recommend every day though or your arteries will scream in agony).  Anyway, for the longest time in my mind Japan was a travel destination I felt was too expensive for me, cause that's the image created about it. But seriously the biggest part was the flight itself, rest all was just like any other bigger city trip.

we did a almost 4 week trip to japan for 2500 including flying(800 euro 2 luggage below and 1 hand and 1 personal item), shinkansen(railpas for 3 weeks) food and hotels(mostly hostels, cabin hotel 2 small hotels and 1 week at someone home ) around 2000 we got for the trip + food , the 500 rest was for personal use (souvenirs).   but we booked all quite early ( a year or half year before ) and we went in summer period that is one of the most expansive for flights.   BTW in the end we got 600 euro back from our flight due to a cancelation, so in the end we spended more that 500 on souvernirs but for 2500 you can come very far for 4 weeks

When it comes to buying airplane tickets: I put all of my regular monthly expenses on the same credit card (bills, supermarket, etc), and just pay it off immediately after my purchase so I don't accumulate interests. That way I accumulate a lot of reward points on that same credit card, and I end up having a lot of them that I can use towards the purchase of airline tickets.  When it comes to food, if I'm staying in a place where I can cook, I do so as often as possible from simple recipes I already know well. I don't know how it is in Japan, but in a lot of places buying stuff at the supermarket and cooking is cheaper than eating out, and that way you can splurge on a few really nice dinners out without going out of your budget.
